body: Excellent product. Exceeds my expectations. Very good camera, both indoors and night mode. Excellent fluidity.
nice phonne for a cheaper price!!

I received this phone for Christmas. It's been great so far. I even already received my Marshmallow update. The battery life is great especially compared to my last phone that I had for several years, and the camera is miles better than what I usually see on an Android. I like the removable back plate that you can change out if you wish. The phone being water-resistant is great, too. This does not mean you should wash it in the sink, but if it's raining or you set it in some condensation from your cup, it's gonna be fine as long as you have secured the back plate.

All in all, I'm pleased with this phone and I hope it continues to perform well.

Update: I don't know if I ended up with a dud, but for some reason this phone started running super slow, almost to the point of not being usable. I hate to restart it every day in order to use it as a regular phone (texting/phone calls). The audio playback was weird. It would only play a few seconds of a song, or any audio, skip ahead, play a few more seconds, unless I re-winded it back to the beginning. It was bizarre and annoying especially while driving. Sometimes it would just restart itself. I had a 32gB SD card that worked wonderfully for about 3 weeks. Then it randomly wouldn't read it. I would turn off my phone, remove the card, turn my phone back on, replace the card and it would work for about 10 seconds; then my phone would restart and no longer read that an SD card was inserted. So any apps I moved would not open and therefore I couldn't move them back to my phone. I really hope this was simply single bad phone, but I am forced to change my rating and hope you guys have much better luck.
Awesome phone for international use. Better than the 2nd generation.
Moto G 3rd Gen survived a plunge into the water with it's Advanced water resistance. It went down under, and it's not 6 feet under!
fit to the price

This phone is sturdy, bright, and fun to use. I really like it. I did my research before I bought this phone and it paid off. When I saw this phone on multiple "Best Of" lists for mid-range phones, I decided to buy it and was not disappointed. I even bought this phone for my father who was weaning himself off of an iPhone 5. He loves it too.

The phone is also supposed to be waterproof. I did accidentally drop it into some water while camping. I took it out of the water, wiped it off, and it was fine.

Downside: I have not found a good case for this phone. I visited multiple phone carrier stores and cell phone accessory kiosks, and no one carried anything for the 3rd Gen. Moto G.

Phone has lots of nice features. Not much in the way of instruction, so helpful to have prior experience with smart phones or to have friends and relatives to ask questions of. One caution: something to check early on is whether you have all of the updated phone software on the phone. I have T-Mobile, and while the phone rang, neither the speaker nor microphone were working. After I exchanged a phone, had the same problem, and then spent 90 minutes with tech support, we found that there was an update for the Moto G that ultimately corrected the problem. I'm guessing that if I'd purchased the phone from Motorola directly, I would have gotten a phone with software updates taken care of. Once we had the software settled, the phone is fun to use and customizable.

Nice, my geeky boyfriend recommended this one to me when my old phone gave up the ghost.  It's much better than the old one; uses battery efficiently, the picture quality and look are just great.  Good value, nice phone!

Hard to believe how good this phone is for so little money. Bought this for my 59 year old dad who needed to finally upgrade from his Galaxy S2. I previously had the first Moto G, which I liked very much. This latest one with LTE, high-res camera, 5.2" screen... what a package. Sure, it might be considered a tad bulky in thickness, especially compared to my similarly sized (but slimmer) Moto X 2nd gen. But for 1/3 the price? It's a no-brainer. I've become a Moto user for life. Bummer they're owned by Lenovo now, but I still take some pride in knowing their HQ / R&D center is in my home town of Chicago. Keep up the good work Moto, I'll keep promoting your great products to anyone I can.

There are lags between between opening and closing apps, and it's getting to be incredibly frustrating. Just some quick first impressions.  I really wanted the 2gb Ram/16gb model but it wasn't available and I was hoping to get a feel for the phone early on with some business travel coming up (review is based on the 1gb/8gb model).

Packaging is clean - the device comes in slim packaging compared with previous Nexus 6/Moto E packaging, however is nicely protected.  When unboxing and flipping the phone over the first thing I noticed is the instructions on the back panel of the phone on how to properly remove the cover/reseal it in order to get the best water resistance.  I also ordered a blue cover from Motorola directly which should arrive next week.  While the back cover is removable the battery is not user replaceable - this may be a factor for some but I carry an external battery when travelling for work.

The device itself does not by any means feel like a budget smart phone.  It's leaps and bounds better in terms of overall build quality compared to some recently released devices such as the Huawei P8 Lite or Alcatel Idol 3.  It is also much more refined than last years G and this years Moto E.  The US Model ships with a MicroSD card slot and a single sim card slot (XT1540).  I really like the textured rear cover although the device may end up going into a case - I had never dropped cell phones in using them for 10 or so years until recently when I managed to drop them 2 or 3 times over the course of the past month.

The display seems decent enough for a 720p offering, never for a moment did I look at it and feel it was a huge downgrade over something like the Idol 3 or iPhone 6 (PPI will be somewhat lower however it still offers a nice display and most likely a power savings driving a lower res display).

Performance, while it does not seem to lag by any means is not quite up to par with the afformentioend devices however, as the Moto G - Gen 3 ships with a Snapdragon 410 instead of a 615 as many midrange devices now utilize.  By no means did I feel performance was poor, but when benchmarking/gaming you will absolutely notice a performance delta between the Moto G and something utilizing a SD6xx/8xx.

Performance actually seems better somehow (perhaps a better Android image or maybe because it ships with 5.1.1?) than the Moto E which I haven't tried with 5.1+ quite yet.  I'll update later with experiences once I've had a chance to do so.  Antutu turned a benchmark of 23,282 which is fairly respectable for a budget device - for comparison the 2nd generation Moto G using a SnapDragon 400 turned in a score of 17,000 so there is a significant enough performance boost with the new G - roughly a 27% performance improvement over its predecessor.

Battery Life I really couldnt say quite yet as I have it on the charger right now and haven't had much of a chance to utilize the device operating off of its battery quite yet but I will update the review once I have a chance to further utilize.  I will say the charge time seemed significant however.

Conslusion:
I'm really happy with the device so far and really don't regret purchasing the 1gb model at this point.  I put a 32gb Micro SD card in to provide some additional storage and seemed to be able to move some apps to SD through application manager.  I don't think anyone coming from a previous gen model would be dissatisfied with the changes made to the 2015 Moto G.  I'll update as I have more of a chance to use the device.

-The phone is really comfortable to hand.
-Display seems to be big first time, but when you get used to it other phones' will seem small and not good to eye.
-I liked most of its' functionalities, but i need to say that camera and battery are the best.
-Especially the second one: surfing internet  for couple an hours, reading book, recording video won't empty the battery, in common it will be alive for 24 hours for sure.
-Pics quality is good too.

Con:
-Too many  Motorola apps, that you can't delete. (without rooting)

I got this phone to use primarily for the water resistant capabilities. I intend to use this as my backup phone, once the Moto X Style is released.

Pros
- Water resistant (sort of - see cons)
- Snappy performance, considering the low specs. Compared to HTC One M9, it is noticeably slower, but not by a large margin. Definitely acceptable performance.
- No bloatware, near stock Android experience. This is  important to me because OS stability is a must-have. Have not encountered any substantial bugs or performance issues.
- Moto Assist and active notifications (love this feature). Does not support always-on voice controls (missed this from my Moto X).
- Great camera for outdoors / well-lit environments. Don't expect great night shots, but if taking portraits in a controlled environment using flash, results come out fine. Did experience red-eye effect in several night time flash photos.
- Good screen. Good daytime visibility. Lower resolution is noticeable compared to higher resolution phones. For day to day use, I find this perfectly fine.
- Good battery life. Averaged 3-4 hours of screen on time per charge.
- Price

Cons
- After light exposure to water (submerging 1 foot of pool water for less than 30 seconds), needs to dry several hours before the earpiece / speakerphone starts working again. This could be a problem if you're expecting to make phone calls. I've found myself having to use speakerphone for all my calls until the earpiece dried up.
- Headphone jack does not work, 36 hours after exposure to water. I will likely be returning this unit. Hopefully this is not the case for all Moto G3s. I have not read of any other instances of this occurring.

Conclusion -
I entertained the idea of using this as a primary phone rather than buying the Moto X Style. The only thing holding me back is the camera's nighttime capabilities, and the water resistant issues. If you're not a phone junkie (like me) who needs to have the best of the best, I highly recommend this phone for it's value, simplicity, relatively good camera, and good battery life.

Just received and activated. So far my research has paid off. Definitely didn't have to spend 2-3 tmes as much for a phone. It iS a phone after all.

The display is sharp and attractive. Call quality is clear. The apps load very quickly...if they could respond any more quickly it would have to be an A.I. inside the thing linked to a chip in my head. Video plays smoothly, and although I get sharper pictures on my 4K t.v., It is a phone...after all. I have the 2gb version because the research pointed to that being the preferred model. Had to wait a few months to get that configuration on Amazon, but it was preferred over ordering directly...just in case there was a problem. That may be part of why the speed is good. Nice to have the 32 gb SD card option. Can't think of why other mfgs. would do away with that. (I don't believe in the cloud yet. In olden days it was easy to rob banks because they were just getting security up to speed. I think the cloud is like that-for now.)

The tactile sensors are good for typing and are fairly accurate, even with my fat fingers. Screen rotation works well, but I do wish the home screen would rotate; won't go to landscape view. No onboard bluetooth manager, but the linking software works. Will have to find a decent bluetooth app. Having trouble getting images from my old Galaxy phone onto this unit by bluetooth. Only 2 pics transfered and then only after repeated attempts. Kept getting a ghostly notification that a paired device was sending and asking me to confirm, but there was no confirmation button on the notification window...and then it just vanishes. The xfer then fails.

I will put this unit through paces and will update if anything significant comes up. 4 stars because it's a good phone and great for the value.

Edit: The battery does not last all day. Both days it lasted no more than 16 hours. Web shopping, texts, surfing and an hour of Pandora  took it down 80%. I will activate battery saver and see if the numbers can be improved. If it cannot handle more than that, then video streaming will crush it.

I just looked into getting warranty service.  I can send them back my phone and be without a phone for who knows how long (not a reasonable option in today's day and age) or pay them a $99 deposit and a $25 non-refundable fee for them to ship me a used phone to replace my phone before I then send them my broken phone so that I don't have to be without a phone.
So not only do I have to deal with the hassle of returning a broken phone, I have to pay a $25 fee (14% of the phone's original cost) for the privilege of having my phone's screen fail.
This level of service should be free, not $25.

Recently switched to this phone, replacing my Samsung Galaxy S3.  I've only had the Moto G for a short time, but so far have found it to perform just as well as my old phone (better in some regards, but that's more about the carrier than the phone!) and meets my needs quite well.

Now to be fair, I am not a "power" user of smartphones...that's why I have a laptop.  ;-)  But what I do is, make a few calls each day, send and receive texts, check e-mail occasionally and play a couple of games when I find myself waiting somewhere with nothing else to do.  And when I'm on wi-fi i have used it to watch ESPN or to see what's on Directv and I find the video quality to be fine for that.  Calls are crystal clear and no issues syncing with my cars Sync software for hands free operation.  Haven't taken any "real" pictures yet, (clicked to make sure it works...that's all so far) but based on the specs, expecting it will perform well.  So far i'm finding that I can go 3+ days on a single charge based on my usage, and that is really nice.

Overall I would say if you're looking for a solid dependable smartphone and don't want to spend $500 or more for a flagship phone, give this one a serious look.  It's a nice size phone (without being too large) and feels solid in your hand.  Add a 32gb SD card, like I did, and you have ton's of storage a decent processor and the latest version of Android to boot!

P.S. Just to clarify, i purchased the 16gb/2gb ram model.  Based on technical reviews I had read, the 2gb of ram should help a lot with performance.

This is a great phone at a great price. I'm very happy with all the features (screen, camera, call quality) but unfortunately it just doesn't have enough storage space. The problem is that out of the 8GB of storage you only get about 4.5GB of actual space.. This means that after installing  as little as 10 or so apps (or 2 big games), you will run out of storage. One would think that adding a SD card would be a cheap way to solve the problem (that's what I did), but unfortunately Android handles the SD card different than main storage so, although helpful for pictures and music, most apps won't install on the SD card (and the ones that do, will only install partially). So do yourself a favor and get the 16GB version which gives you almost triple the storage space available for apps (about 12GB). This extra space for apps (and not having to monitor your storage space all the time) are well worth the extra money.

I found myself suddenly in the market for an unlocked phone after killing my Nexus 5x accidentally. Based on the reviews (lots of contributions which were very helpful, and why I'm writing this - to try to return the favor) I picked up this Moto G 3rd Gen 16GB.  The waterproof feature, expandable memory, and better than decent (to sum up what i learned in other reviews) camera, build quality, as well as the promised battery life ("all day long battery') were big selling points. I figured with the less than bleeding edge processor and the lower pixel density on the screen it would deliver, despite the battery not being "huge". After a week with it, I'm returning it.

Here's what the Moto G delivered on:
*Expandable memory (sort of - the apps i tried to use when the SD card was set as 'internal[' didn't see the SD card as internal). It was cool to be able to load most of  my music on to the card and not worry about streaming it from the cloud and burning up data - I could listen to whatever I felt like and not have to think it through and strategize around storage limitations and data availability/limits
*Camera was as advertised, though i didn't have time to use it in a lot of different situations. Quick to focus, nice quick adjustments (white balance) in the app
*Build quality was solid - a little dense in the hand, but really felt solid like it could handle a little life abuse and no worries
*Screen - looked great. Sharp, good color balance

What was OK:
*Performance - speed, power, smoothness were all decent. Not as good at the 5x, of course, but I could live with this phone's performance level.

What it did not deliver on:
*Battery life - just stupid horrible. The phone would churn through 40% of the batter before I left the house in the morning (up at 615, out by 9am). Over the course of the week I tried all the tricks I had used in the past to reduce/eliminate (airplane mode, resetting, deleting apps that check for updates constantly, decreasing email sync frequency, more resets). The original Moto G I have as a back up phone was putting this third generation model to shame. I can leave that old thing sitting around for a couple of days or more just hanging out in standby and the battery life slowly leaks away as expected. Not the case with the 3rd Gen.

I wish I had been able to figure out what the problem was. My best guess was that the TMO LTE band 4 in my area is just not good enough to keep the phone happy and not burning up power working the radio to keep connected. Band 12 is in my area, and that is what I'm hoping will make the Moto X Pure a keeper phone

Rating: 4/5

Pros:
-Excellent build quality
-Looks and feels like a far more expensive device
-Stock android runs very fluidly
-Great daylight photographs
-A real brand name means better support and warranty service

Cons:
-Some minor autofocus issues
-Low-light photograph quality is lacking
-Screen isn't the greatest
-1GB of Ram on lower end model can be limiting

Summary:  After playing around with the Moto G (3rd Gen) for a couple of hours I was convinced: this is one of the best sub-$200 phones out right now. The combination of a great build quality, stable operating system and decent camera make it a winner for those who don’t need a high-end device.

-------

Full Review:

Build Quality & Appearance:
When I first picked up the Moto G (3rd Generation) my mind was blown. The build quality of this device is excellent for its price range. The plastic it is made of has a nice texture and is firm: there is absolutely no flex or ‘cheap’ feeling to it. It’s great that the phone has waterproof capabilities too. I wouldn’t personally take it swimming, but it’s just a little bit extra peace of mind. I’m a big fan of the feel of the textured back. It adds a nice edge to an otherwise plain smartphone. The front looks like a standard smartphone and while a bit boring I couldn’t find anything to fault with it.

Screen Quality:
The screen is one of the more disappointing parts of this device. It is 720p, and even with a smaller screen size it is possible to see individual pixels. There is a “screen-door” effect, meaning that the black lines between pixels are slightly visible. That being said, the screen has quite nice color and tonal range and it looks good from most angles. The screen is not a deal breaker, but I wish Motorola had sourced a 1080p screen for this device, especially at the higher price point of the larger storage model.

Performance & Storage:
The touch screen is quick and responsive and the U.I. runs extremely smooth even on the 1GB ram / 8 GB rom version. I would suggest getting the 2 / 16 GB version when it becomes more readily available but if you’re a light smartphone user the smaller storage space will be enough. This phone offers expansion via Micro SD so you can store media including pictures and videos on it.

Camera:
One feature that surprised me about The Moto G (3rd Gen) was how good daylight photographs are. After having used a dozen budget smartphones in this price range, I wasn’t expecting much. Previous generations of this phone haven’t had the best camera so I wasn’t expecting much, but it seems Motorola has really stepped up their game and used a sensor was great colour, adequate detail and speedy shooting.

Despite having excellent daylight photo quality, there were a few issues I noticed with the camera. First, the autofocus in the default camera app was quite poor. It would lock focus on an object then not refocus fast enough. Often, this meant I would miss focus. When I touched to focus it would often choose to focus on the object beside the one I tapped on. It is possible to mitigate the autofocus issue with a different camera app installed. Second, night time photography suffered from severe noise and detail loss. They were still far better than other phones I've used at this price point, but not as good as higher end models.

Audio Quality and Signal:
Through my time with the device I didn't have any issues with audio quality or signal. Calls were clear and callers said I sounded good to their ear. The speaker wasn't as loud or clear as it could be, but it was better than many other budget devices I have tried. Media audio through the headphone jack was fine. Wireless stayed connected with no noticeable lag nor signal loss.

Battery Life:
Battery life is decent. With moderate to heavy use I got just over a day out of it, occasionally rounding off into the second day. This is with some text messaging, taking a few pictures, browsing the web for a while, social media and listening to music. It nearly matches any flagship device, which is quite astounding at this price point, though the heaviest of users still may not find it enough. It's worth noting that there is no removable battery so if you do run out you will need a portable battery or a wall outlet.

Conclusion:
I’m thoroughly impressed with what Motorola has put together. With most budget smartphones some things are sacrificed in order to keep the cost low. Other than the screen, this phone is on par with many of the budget phone specs in its price range. It’s not a phone for power users but most people would be happy with it. The Moto G (3rd Gen) would be a perfect buy for casual smartphone users and those who don’t need all the big specs of a high end device.

Robert D.
DrekiTech

So, I've been using cell phones for 21 years and have gone from the analog into the digital world as it has become available.  My smart phones have been the following:
Moto Q - Windows
HTC Touch Pro - Windows
Droid X
Droid RAZR (not the MAXX)
Galaxy S4

My first Moto was the best overall experience for the time.  It was consistent and predictable.  However, the X and RAZR were horrible, and I can probably blame a lot of that on the bloated updates that Verizon pushed out that made a mediocre phone a useless piece of junk.  I can say the same for the GS4.  All of these generally were better suited as a pocket heater than a phone.  I would have gone back to that Q if I could have.

As my contract expired with Verizon, I was looking at my options.I swore I would never buy another Motorola product again, but after looking at what is out there, I couldn't help but come back to the Moto G3.  I can't justify the $600 price of a "flagship" Samsung, and honestly didn't need the overhead of Knox.  I also use my phone as a corporate device, so because of MDM policies, I'm not a rooter.  The balance of features on this phone for the price was undeniable.

At the time of purchase, there was a price drop on the Moto X 2014, but I can't own a phone without SD expansion (bye bye Samsung). So, I ordered the 16/2GB for me and my wife.  Two phones for less than the price of one flagship.  I've also dumped Verizon and went to Cricket.  Again, it's a balance of cost/function.

The unboxing was standard, with nothing exciting (as it should be, it's just a box you throw away).  I powered it up and immediately updated both to Marshmallow and performed a FDR.

Pros:
PURE ANDROID - NO CARRIER BLOAT!!!!
Phone is perfectly responsive.
Multi tasking is excellent.
I get a full day of usage without even trying. (unlike GS4)
Zero screen glitches/lag. (unlike GS4)
When I pick up my phone it is COLD to the touch. (unlike GS4)
Front-facing speaker eliminates the old hand-cup trick. (unlike GS4)

Cons:
There is a software feature by Motorola that decreases ringtone for the first 2 seconds, due to a front-facing speaker.  This was needed on the G1 and G2 as there was only one speaker and it was to prevent someone going deaf if a call came in while holding it up to their ear.  Since it has two speakers, I don't see this as necessary.  I hope Motorola sends out an update to allow users to disable it.  This makes Facebook messenger pop notifications silent (as FB identifies their notifications as a ringtone and not a notification).
No Gyro means no Google Cardboard.
No NFC
non-replaceable battery
Slow charging (Even with my Anker fast-chargers)
Wi-Fi connectivity issues with Cisco APs. (See update below)

So, again, for the price, the pros heavily outweigh the cons and I feel that this phone is a definite upgrade over my GS4.

Motorola, you have redeemed yourself with this phone.  It appears that the changes made by Google were successful and I hope that Lenovo continues that push.

***Moto, please fix the ringtone and allow a few more milliamps while charging (Snapdragon 410 supports Quick Charge 2.0).  These are both software changes and would leave me super-impressed.  I know you don't want to compete with your X platform with Turbo, but a slight uplift in charging wouldn't hurt.

Update:
After a couple months of use, I have discovered a Wi-Fi connectivity issue with commercial grade Cisco devices such as the Aironet line. There will be issues from not being able to obtain an IP address to random drops with no ability to reconnect. Hundreds of other devices from Samsung to Apple mobile products and various laptops have no issues at these sites. Moto escalated support has been very responsive, but no fix. I believe that it is a problem for both Moto and Cisco to fix together, but that's not going to happen.

I'm writing this from the POV of someone moving to this phone from an iPhone 6.

TL;DR: I miss the ability to unlock my phone with a finger print. That's  the only feature I miss from the iPhone 6. Otherwise, I don't feel like I'm skimping on anything having left the iPhone 6.  Android Marshmallow's facial recognition to unlock the phone is good, but does not work in all light conditions - so I really miss this.

LONGER REVIEW:
First, I am not experiencing any of the screen or Bluetooth issues others report here. I am using an AT&T GoPhone SIM card and no issues with call quality, line dropping etc. I've connected this phone to a wide array of devices: my Toyota's built in BT; my PS Audio Sprout amp; a portable BT speaker; my Macbook Pro etc. No issues at all. That's just not happening to me.

Screen: it can be made bright, but also like the built-in ambient light setting that will adjust the screen brightness based on the ambient light in the room. Sometimes I override this and crank up the brightness when necessary.

Ergonomic design: overall, phone feels comfortable in my hand. I got a slim-fitting case to protect against drops, and it still feels good to hold.

Functionality: Well, this really depends on whether your like Android OS or not. I personally think Android has come a hell of a long way since it's introduction.  I'd go as far as saying Android actually surpasses iOS in some areas.
But more importantly, I will give Motorola Mobility props for keeping the OTA operating system updates coming.
I bought this phone Nov. 2015 and the Marshmallow update came in early February -- I feared not getting any updates after purchasing this phone since Google sold this division to Lenovo. Hope to keep seeing the updates coming.

I personally have no issues with Android - and in fact, I use my phone for more media consumption than my old iPad 2. I use a Macbook Pro and there are times I don't want to lug around and open up a computer to browse the web. This phone gets a major workout EVERYDAY by me and it has never let me down.  Having said that, you can double-tap the home button to see all apps running and kill those you don't need to save memory and battery cycles. But overall UI response is fast and snappy.

Battery life for me has been good -- I can get at least a day and half between charges. However, I also of in the habit of turning off WiFi and Bluetooth if they are not needed. I also run my screen at the halfway point most of the time (and no, I don't feel like I am sacrificing legibility doing that).

I haven't had to find out how important the waterproofing is, but I'm glad it is.

Misc. Cons:
No NFC - so no Android Pay (not in widespread use here in the U.S. anyway, so don't feel like I'm missing out)
Android phone styles overall are a bit generic, and the Moto G is no different in this regard, but not a huge issue to me. Function is more important than form in my book.
Camera could be better: it's great for bright light situations, not so much for low light (expect grain in your bar room selfies ;-)
Like iCloud on iOS, Google Photos will automatically sync pictures to the cloud for storage and sharing with others. My wife is still on an iPhone 6, and I installed the Google Photos app on her phone -- now our photos are always in sync!

That's all for now -- I'll edit this review if something crops up.
But for now, totally glad I got this phone -- it's great value for the price and I do not feel like I took a step down when I left the iPhone 6.
This may not be Motorola's flagship phone (that'd be the Moto X Pure edition probably), but it's a damn good phone and one I would recommend to friends and coworkers.

I am in love with this phone! I find it is a very good deal for its price. I have the black version and I feel that it is pretty classy. The phone is pretty big, bigger than an iPhone 5, but can still fit in pockets.

I'll start this review by saying that, for $220, even some time after release, the 2015 Moto G is still the best all rounder you can get for that price. Other offerings like the Asus Zenfone 2 come with their own offerings, but may present their own caveats (for the aforementioned example, bloat and a lack of expandable storage). And there's a lot to love about the Moto G; it's super zippy, it's water resistant, the camera is better than it deserves to be on a phone in this price bracket, and the only thing I can point to where I can say "that's where they cut the price" is in the lack of extras like a gyrometer or NFC functionality. Honestly, it's the best phone a person should be able to ask for given the price.
That being said, the gap between these lower mid tier phones and high end phones got a whole lot smaller since the Moto G came out, and spending just a bit more on a better device may be a better option. To put it into perspective, the newly freely purchasable One Plus X costs thirty dollars more and comes with a full 1080p display, NFC, better build quality, a gyrometer, and a significantly faster CPU (though with stock Android on the Moto G, you probably won't notice much of a performance gap with regular day to day use, even with the Snapdragon 410 inside the Moto). The story is similar with slightly older, yet still entirely capable and massively discounted devices, such as the Nexus 5 or the LG G3. What I'm saying is that this phone fits into a specific niche for people who abosuletly can't spend any more than $220, and can deal with some of the downsides like a lower quality display (720p is still fine at 290 something PPI, though you can still see the grid of pixels if you look close enough or at an angle) and don't mind the lack of graphical horsepower or gyrometer (for things like Google Cardboard). It's a good, solid phone, but Moto's history of dominance in the budget phone market is quickly being encroached upon, and there are better out there. That all being said, the 2015 Moto G is still a good deal that's well worth the price, just make sure to shop around a little before you decide to buy.

I just got this phone yesterday, so it's little more than 24 hours of use, but so far, I really love it. Screen resolution is fine. Camera, in my limited use so far, is fine. I haven't yet shot video, which I do quite a bit on a phone, so can't comment on that. Battery life and responsiveness are better than my 2 year old Samsung, though that's to be expected.

All in all, I'm a fan.

My first smart phone, and I absolutely love it. Real Android (5.1.1 as of last update), great screen, good call quality (all cellphones aren't that good), excellent connectivity on WiFi and 4G. Works GREAT with Cricket Wireless. I get 4G LTE in strong signal areas, HSPA in my home which has a fair to poor signal. Calls always go through just fine, even in my low signal home.

I selected Cricket Wireless as my carrier, and bought the BYOP kit from Amazon. Works great, but read the caution below. Solution is to make sure you buy a MicroSIM kit for BYOP.

The only caution is that the box has an icon showing Micro SIM OK, nanoSIM Bad!. Googling this, I found that the electrical contacts for the SIM slot can catch on NonoSIM to MicroSIM adapters if the SIM card is removed. This is the case for me, since I chose Cricket Wireless (ATT Prepaid) as my carrier. Since I don't intend to remove the SIM, it isn't a big problem. Knowing about the problem, should I need to remove the SIM (to change carriers, for example), I will need to take care extracting the Cricket NanoSIM. You can google the method, which is not complicated, and is essentially slipping a very thin piece of plastic (like screen protector plastic) into the SIM slot before gently removing the NanoSIM

I ordered the Moto G 3rd gen 16 GB via the Motorola.com site but felt that I should write a review for it. Immediately after receiving the phone yesterday, I opened the package, turned the phone on, and started to explore its features and capabilities.

My first impressions: I really liked the design (it is small enough for one hand yet large enough to view everything comfortably and rather thin and light) and the display (sharp for a 720p screen). Coming from iOS and not using Android except to help my family to troubleshoot their devices, I found the layout intuitive and easy to navigate. The phone seemed responsive enough and was enjoying the experience so after less than one hour of use I inserted a new SIM and called my service provider to activate the phone.

After getting off the phone, approximately one hour after opening the Moto G, I noticed a thin bright blue line running vertically the full length of the screen---I assumed defective pixels. I immediately called Motorola support. The tech advised me to return the phone and transferred me over to customer service. I could barely understand the rep not only because of a poor connection (it was obviously overseas) but also b/c English was not her native language. After much deciphering she told me that I had 2 choices: they could sent me a refurbished phone immediately and place a small charge on my credit card which would be refunded when the defective phone was returned, or pay $24.99 to have the phone I just received repaired. When I reiterated that I had just received this brand new phone merely an hour ago and that I was shocked that they would not send me a new phone to replace it, she merely restated what I was already told.

I hung up and called another customer service rep to be absolutely certain that what I was told by first rep was truly the company policy. Again this rep was difficult to understand and the connection poor (another overseas call) but gave me the exact same choices as the first rep.

I then went to Motorola.com and requested a total refund. There was no way I was paying money to fix a defective phone and I hadn't ordered and purchased a new phone only to get stuck with a refurbished one (no one offered me a reduction in price to tempt me). Their policy makes no sense. I just now ordered an Alcatel Idol 3 to try so hopefully have better luck.

Oh.....another thing possibly found......my SIM got activated and I can access the info on my carriers website but the Moto G is not reading it at all. It is a brand new SIM so I am not sure if the problem lies with the SIM card itself or the Moto G. Because I read another review of someone having problems with the SIM card, I'm more suspicous it is the Moto G. I will try to update this review when I get the new phone to verify if it is the phone.

UPDATE 10/9/15: I put the SIM in my new Alcatel Idol 3 and it worked. I did clean the SIM card beforehand with alcohol so who knows. But, in hindsight I am so glad I got a defective phone because I am absolutely loving the Idol 3! The display is the biggest difference--so much better than the Moto G for nearly the same price. I wasn't sure about the bigger size but I'm actually enjoying a bit more screen for viewing.

As carriers are now dropping contracts and people have to pay full price for their phones (either up front or via monthly installment plans), folks are soon going to realize, "Oh wow - that fancy phone really IS going to cost me $700!!".  So once this sinks in, many will eventually realize that most don't really NEED phones in the $500-$850 range.  Enter the Moto G.

First it's important for people to realize that there are two variations of this newest model (3rd generation).  For around $179 you have a version that has 8 gigs of built-in storage, and for around $229, you have one that has 16 gigs of built-in storage.  Both will allow you to add up to a 32 gig micro SD card to add to that (some report success using higher capacity cards, others report glitches).  There is one other rarely advertised difference, though - the 16 gig version comes with TWO (2) gigs of RAM, while the 8 gig version only comes with ONE (1) gig of RAM.  RAM allows you to multitask more apps, speeds up app opening and closing a bit, and can in some cases help some with certain types of video use.  So, should you splurge on the model with more RAM?  Maybe - see below...

I first tried out the lesser of the two models and it did fine with everyday tasks like talking, texting, checking Facebook/Twitter, etc.  But when I tried a more intensive app like Periscope (a video social media app), I noticed the phone at times, sporadically, sputtered and occasionally a green 'flash' would appear on my video broadcasts that both I and those watching me, could see.  I also noticed that the 'available' internal memory was just under 4 gigs of the 8 claimed, due to the OS and other things pre-installed.  So, I took it back and instead ordered this one, with more internal memory and that extra gig of RAM.  I can see a difference.  Apps open fractionally faster, Periscope video broadcasts flow flawlessly, and it just has a more "smooth" operating feel than the lesser spec version - though again, for people who ONLY want a phone for basic social media, email, etc... the $179 version of this phone would probably be fine.

The 5 inch 720p screen is bright and detailed.  The 13 megapixel rear camera is leaps better than previous Moto models, though not quite as good as flagship phones upon full sized inspection.  But since 85% of people who take photos with their cell phones rarely (if ever) actually print them, much less print them in larger sizes, I really don't think this is going to be an issue for most people.  The photos are still nice and details in decent to good light - suffering from noise/grain a bit once the light goes down.  The front facing 5 megapixel camera is very capable and detailed, but lets in slightly less light than those from the higher dollar flagship phones - in other words, you may need more light in the room when doing those selfies or video chats.  Battery life is fine - if you're a VERY heavy user you're going to top-up before the day is done, but for low to medium users you should make it through the day. Adding to this is splash-resistance, so that helps if you get caught in the rain... just don't submerge it.

Mine was the unlocked version and I installed a Tracfone GSM micro sim card in it and it worked just fine.  It should work equally as well with AT&T and T-mobile sims but I'm told it will also work with the likes of Verizon sim cards too - I wasn't able to test that, though.

PROS:  Affordable. Good screen for price. Updates to Android 6.0.  Decent battery life.  Improved cameras over previous models.  Micro SD card capable.  Speedy and fast (especially the $229 version with the extra RAM).

CONS:  Volume buttons are in the middle-center of the right side, so for some, this is where you grip the phone, causing possible accidental button pushes - once you get a decent case on it, it stiffens that area up some and helps remove the problem.  Rounded shape of back creates a 'rocking' motion if you try to lay it flat on a table and text that way.

I wanted to comment on the single issue I've run into in my short time with the Moto G (3rd generation) phone. The plastic shell on the back of the phone does not seal properly around the "bottom corner hole" (as it is described in the user manual). This is the point where you use your finger nail to pry off shell, and they specifically say to not "use tools to remove the cover" but that it may require a "little muscle." I don't know if it was loose out of the box, but when I pried off the back to insert the micro SIM and microSD cards and replaced the shell I noticed that it would not click securely closed at the bottom corner hole. I don't know if it's because of a fault in the shell or in the body of the phone (I'd assume it's a problem with the shell as the nub that fits into the back of the phone body is slightly shorter than the one on the opposite side). I have tried a number of times to replace the back shell with no luck securing this one corner. The shell is relatively secure, and obviously this doesn't affect the phone's functionality. However, the water resistance requires a tight seal. I have ordered a replacement shell to determine if it is a fault with the shell or the body of the phone. I'll update when I receive the shell.

Update: 8/19/2015
I purchased a replacement shell directly from Motorola ($14.99 + $5 shipping), and the shell snapped securely closed at the bottom corner. The problem appears to reside in the shell that I received with the phone, and not the body of the phone. I would caution repeatedly taking the shell off as the nubs that snap into the body could become worn down. This entire review has been about the shell, the one complaint I've had. In the week I've been using this phone, I've been extremely happy with the phone's performance (smooth transitions between applications), the practically pure Android lollipop experience (5.1.1), and long battery life (easily a full day including video conferencing for ~1 hr). I'm upgrading the rating to 5 stars from 4 (my true score would have always been somewhere in between), and I would strongly recommend this phone to anyone interested in getting a new Android phone at a budget price.

I switched over from an HTC One M7 and couldn't be happier. It gets reception in areas where my previous phone didn't, has ridiculously long battery life, and is much smoother to use (on paper, the processor isn't as good, but the lack of bloatware makes up for it in terms of performance).

The only software additions that Motorola has are genuinely thoughtful, like the motion gestures (chop twice to activate flashlight, twist twice to activate camera) and Moto Display. With Moto Display, the phone can tell when you pick it up from a table or your pocket, and gives a quick, battery-friendly view of the time and any notifications you might have, all without having to press the unlock button. From there you can choose to unlock into the app with the notification, unlock to the home screen, or ignore it and it'll go away after a couple seconds.

The heavy-duty water resistance is a nice touch as well; combine this phone with a durable case and I think it will last a very long time. For anyone who doesn't use their phone for heavy graphics-intensive gaming, I don't think it would be possible to go wrong with this one.

+1 for the 5 stars!
I decided to try this flagship-specs-for-budget-price deal and was not disappointed.
Initially I had trouble connecting the phone to my bluetooth car kit, but after the upgrade to Android 6 (OTA Dec 24th, smooth upgrade) that also has been working flawlessly.
Love the smoothness and battery life.
Camera pictures seem a bit less lively then Samsung/Iphone, which could also be related to the screen/display itself.
But as a whole this phone truly delivers.

The 8GB version, with 1GB of RAM, is perfectly useable. Tests on YouTube show no discernible differences in responsiveness between this and the 2GB version. I wouldn't have wanted this screen and somewhat budget features for over $200. At $180 (I paid $150 for a like new) it's a good deal for a good Android experience that will only get better with 6.0.

The storage does go fast but I still have a solid 2GB of space for updates and eventualities. Android 6.0 will allow for better offloading to an SD card of apps and app related junk. Long overdue. And I expect that update to come before the end of the year, if not the end of October. Perfectly fine for people who want/need a logical amount of apps. Not for the person who needs 100-plus apps.

Waterproof is nice because I like to get out into the weather. Motorola's proprietary features are great.

Do yourself a favor if you are getting this phone. Get the 16GB model. It only has about 5 GBs of usable memory. 3 of the 8 is taken up by the OS. And memory will fill up fast on this phone, especially with how heavy today's apps are. And once this phone gets to filling up, it slows down, a lot. When I first got the phone it performed beautifully. Now it struggles and crawls to open apps. When apps finally do open they are sluggish and crash constantly. I'm also constantly going into the storage management to delete caches and other useless data just so the phone can work again. Really wish they were more open with how much memory this phone actually had. Its a really good phone when it works, but most of the time it's is really too sluggish to use. And once that happens, the battery starts to go with it. Really disappointing. Because other than that it's a great phone.

this might be the best smart phone i ever had, Amazing, my last few phones have been a couple of iphones, I think the last one was the 5s, then a Galaxy note 2, great phone, my favorite until the moto, I bought also a Blu life pro, (terrible phone) and now the Moto, I think I am in love

Used to have the moto g 2013, so i decided to trade up and try the 3rd gen.

The Good:
-Great phone for the price!
-Nice 5" screen, not superb, but very very nice quality and colors
-Good loud speaker, even if it only has one (why would you need stereo speakers on a cellphone anyway?)
-Battery life is enough to get you through your day in a normal usage: email, chat,calls, a bit of gaming, a bit of video, a bit of surfing, a bit of everything,
-Camera takes good quality pictures (better than the old moto g 2013)
-Almost Vanilla Android, with no bloatware, just a couple of apps from motorola that they are actually usefull!
-Guaranteed upgrades: Old moto g1 got lollipop and it runs smoothly. The 3rd gen moto runs lollipop 5.1.1 and runs very very smooth, no lag so far
-Moto maker!
-Micro sd card up to 32GB helps out with your memory (there some websites saying that they have tested 64GB microSD and working "fine", however, i would go for the 32 just to be safe)
-Water resistance!

The bad:
-8GB is nothing, you'll get about 4GB, almost 5GB of free memory to install apps, phone cache, etc. Go for the 16GB and 2GB RAM version, you will tell the difference
-Yep, 720 by today standards is pretty much acceptable, but 1080 would have been much appreciated...however i understand that is all about price.
-Stock camera app wont let you change the pixels size of the picture, but there are workarounds for that
-No Gyro (although personally i dont care)

All in all, it is a great phone either for beginner or advanced user. Don't get confused about the snapdragon 410, it is a 64 bit processor more than capable to take on any app that you can throw at (Yes, moto g1 had a snapdragon 400, but it was 32bit, there's a difference)

Something i noticed, when using the 4G network, my phone used to get a little warm when watching videos (youtube, netflix) or surfing heavy sites (not much, just a bit warm), however, turned back to 3G/H+ and the warm decreased a lot! I know some people might think "well that's a huge stepback, going from 4G to 3G/H+", but...really? how often do we really use 4G? Pretty much everywhere we go, work, home, friend's home, restaurant, caffé, they all have WiFi...the only time not using WiFi is during car travel, and if you are using yourphone while driving...just be careful...

To wrap it up, you wont regret getting this phone. I dont give 5 stars because nothing is perfect.

My last phone was the Moto G 4G LTE 1st Gen.  I liked that phone, but over time, with the firmware updates and increased demands from apps, along with only 8gb of internal memory, it had clearly run its course.

The Moto G (3rd Gen) is fantastic. The extra gig of RAM is obvious. There is almost no lag moving from one app to another. The LTE speeds are clearly present (sometimes I felt that the 1st gen was actually faster at 3G) and browsing is incredible.  The screen is the perfect size. It is smaller than a phablet but larger than the 4.7" phones I've had over the years.

The camera is nice. Moving objects can still blur, but nothing like what the 5mp camera on the 1st gen had.  Still pictures are crisp and beautiful.

I can stream music (Google Music, Pandora, TuneIn) and run my GPS navigation with no lag.

Areas for improvement:  I would love to see NFC technology added to the next gen Moto G (or whatever branding Lenovo goes with).  I would also like to see some kind of finger print tech, though that is probably another year or two from being affordable on the low end phones. Android Pay is the future of point of sale transactions, and I think it will become increasingly necessary, even in budget phones.

Probably the best sub 200$ phone you can buy.  I got it for 100$ at Best Buy (special price match).  Basically the deal of the year lol.

Intuitive android interface, tons of camera features, solid battery life, beautiful Gorilla screen, water resistant, perfect intermediate size (not obnoxiously big or too small), etc.

I personally wouldn't pay 180 for the 8 gig version, due to the fact that I don't like overpaying for phones in general with the risk of theft, loss, or damage, and b/c the gigs included get cut to like 5, but if you can get it on sale, it's still a steal.  Easily the best, most feature-rich phone I've ever owned, and best of all it's unlocked.  The audio for me was the big initial selling point - front speakers, GREAT audio.  Also BLAZING internet speed thanks in part also due to T-MOBILE's LTE.

I will say the reason it's not 5 stars is simple - I had to swap it out 3 TIMES b/c there was tons of confusion initially about why call audio wasn't working upon use - turns out you need to do a system update for 30 MINUTES in order to upgrade to Marshmallow.  Pain in the ass, and wasted a whole day.  Motorola customer service is s***, took hours to figure it out.  T-Mobile didn't know, and Best Buy associate FINALLY figured it out.

Also - you WILL need to download additional apps b/c some of the pre-programmed apps aren't great (such as dialer, clock, media app, etc), and also android doesn't allow you to relocate a ton of apps/data to an SD card on this phone, so that's a con for me as well.  Lastly, Motorola doesn't include a USB for some freakin reason.  That drops the score down a bit b/c that's an accessory you'll have to pay out of pocket for - shame on them for that, most companies now include that for free...utterly ridiculous.

UPDATE: Upgraded to 16 gig/ 2 gig ram  version for a total of $130.00 through Best Buy price match haggling.  Which really IS the steal of the year.  I did so b/c I now believe the 8 gig version, which a nice entry level phone with tons of bonuses, just doesn't provide nearly enough basic ROM necessary to use long-term.  Those 8 gigs turn into 4.5, and after app upgrades, apps, games, media, etc. - well...you get the picture.  And don't even think about getting an SD card for anything other than media - ANDROID doesn't allow to you migrate ANYTHING to them (basically).  So for me, it became 16 gig or bust.  And I'm quite happy with it, aside from a steeper learning curve than I expected (such as having to find apps to sync contacts from old Windows Phone)

2ND UPDATE: Screen does get smudgy with fingerprints, not ideal.  Also, while the battery life is outstanding, the charging time is HORRENDOUSLY slow (like 5 hours for a full charge).

FINAL CONCLUSION:

I've compared this phone to others in the 200$ category, and there's really this, and a few others like the Zenfone and One Touch Idol 3, but that's about it.  As an example - Samsung Grand Prime (somehow gets good reviews?) is a HORRIBLE phone.  Audio is CRAP, not to mention the bloatware.  Right there I knew to skip it.  If you can't enjoy videos/music on your phone, that's a big, immediate no-no from me.  Moto G has some of the best speakers on the market today.  At similar price points, you might get a slightly better processor and screen/camera, but you won't get the well-rounded variety the Moto G provides - water resistance WITH a dual facing, 13/5mpixel camera AND 4GLTE capability; better than advertised real-world processing capability, Gorilla Glass, and Micro SD option.

4/5.

Bought this for my mother for her birtday and I'm jealous I should have gotten for myself.  For a first time smartphone users you can't find a better phone or value. On paper and in the hand, the phone is great value.

However, my phone's SD card was non-functioning which I smoothly initiated an RMA for over their website. FYI there are two RMA options.

1. Print a pre paid shipping label and ship your phone in. Upon receiving, Motorola will issue a replacement phone.
2. Pay $25 (non refundable) and a $100 deposit (refundable) fee and Motorola will ship you a replacement phone and you ship your phone in at your own time. Why anyone would sink more money into this is beyond me.

A week and a half after shipping my phone, I received package. It was my original phone without any repairs made. On top of that, the phone was damaged.

This time I called and requested escalation. The escalation department was not able to offer anything more than the original RMA system. I also had to  Despite talking to the supervisor, they were unable to offer compensation or remove fees for option 2. Effectively the escalation department serves no purpose and customer service does not exist beyond the most basic tier.

TLDR: Customer service is very basic. You can add Motorola to your list of bad companies like Comcast.

Update Nov 9th: Second RMA returned again with nothing fixed. This time I had left notes on the RMA saying what the problems are. I also included a business card with the symptoms written out. Again I was not contacted before they returned my original phone with no repair made.

This was a used Moto G from Digicircle, an XT1540 with no sim. Initially I set it up through my Verizon WiFi jetpack. I was blown away by how easy it was to setup and the big bright screen. Coming from a basic tracfone it was a major jump in every way. Verizon is the only provider in this area of Arizona and this model of the Moto G is a GSM rather than the CDMA I needed to talk or text. So far, so good! The 16 GB model has 3-4 times more space for apps than 8 GB (unfortunately most apps cannot be moved to the external sd card even when it mounted as an internal storage).
Good phone..

Overall I am very happy with this phone. Most of the reviews covered the phone in general so I am not going to discuss the phone itself in depth in this review except for two quick things.

1. One thing that I find annoying about this phone is that it doesnt sit flat on surfaces because of the curved design on the back. The phone will wobble or spin around if you try to use it on a flat surface. Consider getting a case that will allow it to sit flat on surfaces.

2. You should seriously consider the 16gb storage / 2gb RAM model. This is the model I got. On average my phone uses about 1.1GB of memory. I included a screenshot of the memory consumption of my phone. Also, after installing all necessary apps the phone storage space sits at 9.75gb out of 16gb. So you need to decide if the extra $33 is worth it. I included a couple screenshots of the space limitations of this phone.

Camera
I am very pleased with the camera's performance. I got this phone mainly because I didnt want to carry around a camera and a cell phone all the time. I needed to get a new phone but didnt want to pay the price for an LG or iPhone. I find the camera to perform exceptionally well. While there are limitations in the camera app, there are other cool camera apps that could be downloaded that allow for more features.

All the photos attached to this review were taken with the native camera app that came with the phone. The HDR component does an exceptional job in taking outdoor photos.

Flash / Low Light
I took a couple pictures comparing indoor shots with and without a flash. The images are labelled accordingly. I am still not sure about indoor photos and the quality of the flash. In some photos, I felt that the flash sometimes makes the picture look worse. I think this is an overall issue with all smartphones. In very dark situations the quality with a flash was acceptable.

Outdoor
I am very impressed with the quality of the outdoor photos. I really think the photos came out much sharper with the Moto G than with my Panasonic Lumix camera. The camera uses HDR technology which ensures that all elements of the photo come out sharp by taking multiple shots and combining them together for one sharp photo. This means that the image size will much larger when using HDR. This is something else to consider. The non-HDR photos were around 2mb each whereas the HDR images were around 5-6mb each. Included are some really nice landscape and flower shots.

One more thing. The phone recently had a hard fall after I tripped on the stairs (yes I was looking at my phone. I know, I know). This was the second time it fell or perhaps thrown to the hard stone ground. I had the thin clear Pleson case with the Pleson screen protector and the phone didnt have a scratch. The first time it had no case but it did have the Pleson screen protector. It fell scree face down from the table on to a ceramic tiled floor and nothing happened to the screen. Dont waste your money on a bulky otterbox style case. Not needed.

Purchased this phone from the Amazon Warehouse and it came in great condition. Problems started when I turned it on and it asked for the previous email address that was logged on to it. This is a part of Google's Factory Reset Protection, if your phone gets stolen and someone tries to wipe it clean so that they can use it you need to enter that person's email address to gain access to the phone. Since I don't know who the previous owner is, their email address and there is no published, legit work-around for this problem I cannot log into this Google Motorola phone. I contacted Amazon customer service through chat and over the phone and they don't understand the issue so I'm afraid if I reordered the same phone after I return this one that I am going to have the same problem.
Everything went perfectly fine! Even better than expected. Thank you!!!

Pet peeves:
-No notification light, but the Moto Display software makes up for it somewhat.
-Currently has a serious problem recognizing contacts phone numbers (reject installing marshmallow 6.0, as the problem stems from that update, or delete and re-enter your contact synced accounts after it's done)

Overall, you can't go wrong with this one as there's no ugly feature in it.

This phone skipped bootcamp and went right into action.  I bought this phone 5 days before leaving for 22 days in China.  I had just sent my awful LG G3 to Ft Worth for its 3rd attempt at repair and was without a phone.  This little gem had me asking why I ever bought the G3.  By the way, to hopefully save you some trouble, don't buy LG. Their products are shady and their service is despicable. They absolutely refused to replace or reimburse me for my malfunctioning G3--all software related.  Instead they took three swings at repairing it and it still doesn't work right.

But enough of that.  I wanted to praise this wonderful phone. Build quality is very nice. It feels and looks expensive. I'm not exaggerating when I say that the camera is SUPERIOR to the camera in my G3. I've seen a lot of the "jello" wobbly video effect in my G3, which is completely absent from this camera. The colors are rich and vibrant. I carried a Fuji XE-2 camera with me in China, but did use the phone for lots of quick videos and photos. I'm really impressed with the HDR photos and the speed and accuracy and of focus.  Because of the water resistance, I didn't worry about the occasional rain I experienced, though I tend to throw everything electronic into my backpack when the rain falls.

I used the phone for messaging back home and domestic messaging and calls in China and it worked great.  The US style charging plug that came with the phone was compatible with the sockets in Chinese hotels...though I think that goes for most phones these days.

For surfing the web, the phone is quick and responsive. I can't speak to how it handles gaming, as I haven't yet installed any games.

The phone has no wasteful bloatware, so like a lot of folks say, it's yours to build as you like. I really can't see how you can go wrong with this phone.  Best wishes!

Great phone

I got the chance to play around with this device for a couple days, helping someone to figure out how to use it (who had never picked up a smartphone before) and I was impressed. The most impressive part is that this phone costs under $200, and depending on where you get it (like from a cellular carrier selling it unlocked) it can come in UNDER $170. So it's "cheap" and competes in a crowded arena with some equally great devices in the sub $200-$300 price point. I'll go over those later. The "G" comes in 2 versions: an 8 GB and 16 GB. This one is the 8 GB version. All are GSM quad band devices (you can use them all over the world, and will be 3G compatible) and finally support LTE! It's unlocked so you can use it on any GSM carrier, and it will work internationally (Europe, Asia, Mexico, South America, etc.). For connectivity there's WiFi a/b/g/n, Bluetooth 4.0, GPS with GLONASS and A-GPS, and an FM radio. There is no NFC on the G.

For those curious, the Moto G is Motorola's 2nd-tier smartphone, a step above the sub-$150 Moto E, and it's a pretty nice upgrade. What do you get for under $170 to $200? A lot. The device is definitely not what you'd call "low-end." It's got really generous hardware, a solid build, and a high-quality feel and finish. It's also ruggedized and IPX7 certified (30 minutes water resistance in 3 feet of water) so you can dunk it in the toilet and it will be fine, or drop it in the pool and have a working phone.

It's not a small device, but not as big as the 5.5" phablets. This is a pretty "normal" sized phone. It's 5.5" tall, 2.85" wide by .46" thick. It weighs a little over 6 ounces, so it's not lightweight but not heavy. The back is curved so it fits well in your hand and is comfortable to hold with one hand. The back cover is textured with a grainy soft plastic coating, which doesn't show fingerprints and is really easy to grip. The camera lens also doesn't stick out, so it lays flat on surfaces. It never fell out of my hand. The back is removable, but sadly, the battery isn't. You do get a micro-sim slot and a slot for a 32 GB maximum MicroSD card, which is nice considering a lot of phones are moving away from that.

For the hardware, it comes with a Qualcomm Snapdragon 410, which is a quad-core CPU running at 1.4 GHz, and an Adreno 306 graphics processor (upgraded from the 2nd Gen Moto G's 305), and 1 GB RAM. The 16 GB version has 2 GB, but cost about $40 more, and if you want the most out of the phone, it's a good investment. I'd have liked to see the Snapdragon 615 like on the Alcatel Idol 3, but Motorola had to cut costs somewhere. Plus, the screen doesn't need a lot of processing power and there aren't any 3rd party apps on here to use system resources, so the 410 is perfectly fine.

One of the areas Motorola cut costs is in the screen. Instead of a 5.5" full HD screen with 400+ pixels per inch (PPI), you get a 5" 720p HD IPS touch screen with 295 PPI covered in Gorilla Glass 3. It's very vivid, the colors are bright and accurate, and it's extremely responsive to touch. Text and graphic are sharp and you have to look real hard to make out individual pixels. Great for reading and viewing videos. The screen itself isn't edge-to-edge and has about a 3/8" bezel top and bottom. There are no physical front panel buttons, and only two physical buttons on the right side of the device for power/lock, and volume. The buttons have an excellent feel and presses are very solid, and the power button has a textured finish.

There is a single speaker below the screen. The 2nd Gen Moto G had stereo speakers, but this one only has a single speaker (the Alcatel Idol 3 has two stereo speakers). For the record, the audio quality from the speaker is excellent. Loud, not very tinny like some at high volumes, and even a little "bassy"  but not like the Alcatel Idol 3. The speakerphone is great. As good or better than the ones on $600 devices. There's also a dedicated active noise-cancelling microphone.

Motorola took the camera from the Nexus 6 and stuck it in the Moto G, so you get a 13 megapixel camera with a wide f/2.0 aperture. It comes lightly equipped with geotagging, face detection, auto HDR (high dynamic range), 4x digital zoom, autofocus, panorama mode, low-light mode, and adjustable brightness and exposure. There's a dual-tone flash that doubles as a video light. Not a lot of features or shooting modes, and no manual controls for the camera, but it's good as it is. There's a 5 megapixel front camera as well for selfies. The Moto G shoots full HD videos as well, but the front camera only does VGA resolution.

The operating system is what I love about the Moto G. Out of the box it needed a software update to run Android Lollipop 5.1.1, and it's "vanilla" Android, so there's no user interface and NO bloatware, which is awesome because half of all the preloaded apps that come on phones these days is useless to me and takes up storage and system resources. Not so with the G. You get all the basic Google apps like Google Now, Google+, YouTube, Facebook, Picasa, Amazon, and others. Just real basic. No carrier-installed rubbish. Google Now is Siri's little sister and works really well- "OK Google...." works great. There's rumors that Motorola will be patching the Moto G with Marshmallow 6.0 here soon.

The G comes with Android Lollipop. This was my first time using Lollipop and it was a really good experience. Motorola kept the App Drawer, and the pull-down menu has 2 stages, one for apps and notifications, and another for the pull-down menu. Very easy to use and the menus and features are well laid-out and easy to find. My parents never used or owned a smartphone before, and they are learning how to use the G really quickly! Everything you can imagine is customizable on the G. Like the Nexus phones, there's no manufacturer-installed user interface, so you get the clean version of Android, which is really easy to use. There's no ridiculous and unnecessary apps to navigate so the app drawer isn't very full and easy to negotiate for a first-time user.

So how does the G do? I think it was really great. The phone is fast and performance is snappy. Motorola did a good job matching it with the 410 processor. I never had an issue with lagging when switching between menus or apps, launching apps was fast, and having multiple apps running at the same time didn't slow it down. I ran Maps and it runs really well. There will be some cases where it will bog down, like when playing games or a video at the same time, or during intensive multitasking. That's due to the 1 GB RAM. The Snapdragon 410 was plenty powerful enough. Don't expect amazing performance or gameplay though. The Adreno 306 is only marginally better than the 305 in the old Moto G. Expect this phone to be as good as the others in this price bracket. Web browsing (I use Dolphin Browser) was really good with the LTE and large screen. Pages loaded quickly and scrolling was smooth and responsive. No issues there. The bummer is the 1 GB RAM. The phone works well with the 1 GB RAM, but to get the most out of it you need the 2 GB. Most all the other budget devices in this class have 2 GB. Data connectivity is the usual GSM, but the Moto G also has LTE (on bands 2, 4, 5, and 7, and 17), so it runs the fastest mobile data out there on just about every major carrier (ATT, Cricket, T-Mobile, Consumer Cellular, Metro PCS). Plus it's factory unlocked so all you need is a SIM card to run it on any GSM carrier. You can also use it as a mobile hot spot. Data speeds on Consumer Cellular were very good with the G. On LTE with good signal strength on the SpeedTest App, I averaged 20 Mbps download and 10 mbps upload. Not bad considering that it shares network capacity with ATT and T-Mobile.

The camera is very good. It's the same one from the Nexus 6, and that's a nice addition considering the price. Like the screen and other hardware, I expected the camera to be one of the areas Motorola had to downgrade to keep the the base Moto G under $200. Don't expect amazing picture quality from this camera, but you will be surprised, especially if coming from devices like the LG Optimus series devices or lower-end Galaxy phones. It has autofocus, but no image stabilization (optical or digital). Daytime pictures looked really nice with decent amounts of detail and the color reproduction was very good and there's little image processing so time between shots was very low- well under a second between from focus to finished picture. It's a tap-to-focus and there's no on-screen focus or shutter button, so that made it a little hard to get used to. The camera menu is accessed by swiping to the left across the screen and scrolling vertically through the menus. Surprisingly, nighttime shooting was disappointing without the flash, despite the f/2.0 lens. It's not terrible, and a lot better than other "budget" smartphone cameras and on par with the competitors (Asus Zenfone 2, Alcatel Idol 3), but image quality drops off considerably without the flash, which was nice and bright and didn't turn the pictures blue or overexpose them. The images with the flash came out warm and natural-looking. The useful range of the flash is capped at 3 meters in a pitch black room.

The Lithium ion (not polymer) battery seems small at 2470 mAh, but it lasts a long time in this phone. The screen is small and doesn't use a lot of power despite being LCD and not LED. The processor doesn't use a lot of power either, so you'd have no trouble getting a full day out of the G with battery to spare at the end of the day. I'd say you could go a full day and a half to two days without charging it under normal use. It doesn't have wireless charging or quick-charging capabilities, but you can't expect that from a sub-$200 handset. The only bummers with this phone is the lack of a removable battery, small screen, no NFC or quick charging, and it only has 1 GB RAM. The 8 GB storage is quickly used (half by the operating system and installed apps), so there's only about 4 GB left to work with, which isn't much these days. Thankfully, Lollipop lets you save apps to the SD card, but the Moto G is limited to a 32 GB max card. Most of the competitors have 64 GB. If you like to download videos and have lots of pictures and apps, then you will need the SD card. Thankfully, SD cards are cheap!

So...

Pros:

Incredible value for the money
Great performance
Rugged and water proof
LTE and quad-band GSM
Battery lasts a long time
Easy to handle
Comes with stock Lollipop Android 5.1.1
MicroSD slot
Very good camera
No bloatware!

Cons:

Only has 1 GB RAM for the 8 GB version
16 GB version is $40 more
SD card limited to 32 GB
No NFC
Screen could be bigger
Graphics processor could be better
Battery isn't removable
A little thick and heavy

I'm a little peculiar with electronics, but I really can't say anything bad about the Moto G 3rd Gen. For the money, it's a fantastic device and I can't see how Motorola got the price under $180 for the 8 GB version (some are under $170). The camera is very good, a huge upgrade over the previous Moto G's and better than some comparable phones in this class. I love the stock Android, it's rugged and water proof, has LTE, and the battery lasts a long time. It's easy to use, and has very good performance. If you think about it, the competition (Asus Zenfone 2, Alcatel Idol 3) are faster, have better screens, and somewhat better cameras, but cost more. If you don't mind the 1 GB RAM, 32 GB SD card limit and 5" screen, then the Motorola Moto G is going to be the lone survivor in the budget phone arena. If you want a great phone for well under $200 (for the 8 GB version) that has some higher-end features and great functionality, then the Moto G is going to be the one I recommend. I am a phone connoisseur, and was impressed with the Moto G. Great phone and the standout in the class. You won't find a better deal in this price range.

I didn't buy on Amazon, but the Motorola website, where you could customize your colors.  I ended up taking the phone back after tremendous amounts of researching and finding nothing that could solve my issue.

Pros:
- Great screen, speakers, buttons, hardware seems nice.
- Supposedly water resistant
- Snappy Android Marshmallow.  No real slow-downs or hiccups from the phone at all.

Cons:
- Battery:  So, it's supposed to have a big battery in it. However, for me it literally took 4-5 hours to charge from 0 (which happened a couple of times, unfortunately).  This charging time is unacceptable for a phone that one uses daily and needs a charge in the morning before going to work.
  Also, if I forget to charge it at night, it will go to 0% and shut down overnight.  All I know is that "Android System" seemed to be the number one culprit on the report.  In typical Android fashion, I hit every setting I could in order to preserve the battery.  I completely turned off data as well.  It could be anything at this point, and got sick of constantly baby-sitting it, so it's going back.
- Occasionally, for some reason, the micro sd card dismounts, with no notification whatsoever.  You have to find out by realizing something that uses the SD Card (like books or music) is missing from the phone.  Even rebooting doesn't mount it.  So, because it's water resistant, you have to take off the back to take out the card, and put it in.  This is very annoying for a new phone and the latest OS.

I really wanted to like this phone.  But something about it (the hardware, OS, etc.) just makes it unreliable to me.  A real let-down.

UPDATE:  Do NOT buy anything from Motorola!  They're customer service is all outsourced, and they all tell you different things.  Still waiting for my refund on this junky phone.  Apple messes up as well, but at least the 3rd time they get the job done.  Spend a little more $$ and buy the iPhone SE.  You'll save yourself a ton of headache.

I purchased my Moto G from Motorola's website.

I've had it for 3 months at the time of this review. The first thing I'll say is that the device has been underwhelming since the minute I opened the box. I realize this is a budget phone, but it was a real let down compared to my Nexus 4, which I purchased years ago for $300 (not a whole lot more).

But I can live with something that is just okay--it's just a phone, right? So I gave it a shot.

Today I contacted Motorola support. I updated the phone to Android 6.0 Marshmallow awhile back, and since then I have had a few days when the device just rebooted without any input from me. After asking me to select some options in Settings which were not available to me, the support person suggested that I need to do a factory reset to resolve the problem. Yes, that kind of factory reset, the kind where you have to back up your data and set up your device anew.

I convinced support to try something else. We are now wiping the cache partition. Hopefully that helps.

At the end of the day, I can't condone this. Deleting a user's personal data and resetting the phone should not be the first thing a support person has to try to get a device working again after an update. I'd go on about the other underwhelming features and petty annoyances of the Moto G, or the fractured and unreliable update ecosystem that is Android, but I'll save you the pain.

I regret not getting a Nexus 5X. Go spend a few dollars more and try that instead.
