UPDATE 1: Downgrading this review to 1 star. This phone is giving me a constant error message that reads: SD Card Was Unexpectedly Removed. And all the photos and apps on the SD card are not accessible until the phone is restarted. Works fine for a while, then it happens again and again. Brand-new SD card, a SanDisk 32GB Class 10. I've owned a lot of Android smartphones and I've never seen anything like this. Same thing happens when other SD cards are tried. Works for a while, then the card crashes. If you Google this, you will see it is apparently a common problem with Motorola phones.

ADVICE: If you buy this phone, DO NOT buy it directly from the Motorola website like I did. Motorola does not make it easy to get a replacement phone. They will try to charge you. Buy it from Amazon where returns are simple and easy.

Original review: This is probably the best "cheap" smartphone you can buy.
I bought three of these for my family and took them to Cricket Wireless for a very good unlimited data, multiple-phone deal.
I have no complaints about the phone except that I've only had it for a week and It needs to go back to Motorola for repairs.
The edges of the screen and the earpiece/speaker are wide and very deep set. These areas collect lots of dust very easily.
I tried to use a very soft toothbrush to GENTLY clear the dust from the earpiece and it immediate punctured the thin waterproof membrane that covers the earpiece. The waterproof membrane covering the earpiece is thinner than paper. It's like rice paper.
So the phone still works, but the waterproofing has been compromised. And it happened very, very easily.
So it will be $70 to ship it back and have it repaired. No fun.
Motorola gives ZERO instructions regarding how to keep the phone clean, but my advice is DO NOT try to brush the dust off.
Ever.
The waterproof membrane is super-delicate and really should be covered by a grille of some kind. It's a design flaw in my opinion.
Other than that, I'm happy with the phones so far. Best deal in mobile!

I bought this phone about two weeks ago as a replacement for my Nexus 5 that died.  The build quality on the phone seems very good and the phone feels solid and durable.  I like the feel of the textured rubber back.  The setup was a breeze - I just inserted my sim card, logged in to my gmail account and created a MotoID.  In terms of performance, the phone feels very similar to my Nexus 5, if not slightly snappier.  It plays Asphalt 8 just fine.  The OS is _very_ close to stock Android like my Nexus was, and I really like the few deviations it has, such as the motion gestures that are actually useful and convenient (you can simply "twist" the phone to launch the camera app or shake it turn the flashlight on or off - even when the phone is off).  The camera takes crisp, sharp pictures, even in some fairly challenging light conditions.  It did struggle a bit with taking pictures of Christmas lights but, admittedly, I was in a hurry and didn't take much care in focusing the camera on the lights or adjusting any of the settings.

Pros:
- "Cheap"
- Solid performance
- Good camera
- Useful enhancements over stock Android
- Waterproof
- Built solid enough that I'm comfortable not using a case with it
- SD Card slot
- Good battery life (1.5-2 days with moderate to heavy use)

Cons:
- A bit bulkier than my Nexus 5, but that is mostly offset by not needing a case.
- Haven't received the Android 6 update yet.

I've been on a smartphone hunt ever since my beloved LG G2 bit the dust a couple months back. Despite being a couple years old, the G2 packed some really premium features into its case, so I was looking for a phone that wouldn't feel like a step back, while still keeping roughly the same form factor (today's top-of-the-line phones are all BIG).

I did a mountain of research and feature comparisons between all the Android phones on the market. I was looking for something that wasn't too expensive (sub-$400), wasn't too big (sub-5.2-inch screen), had an SD card slot for expandable memory, a decent amount of RAM, and a camera that performed okay in low light, but I wanted to believe I could sacrifice a little of all that stuff for a low-cost phone that could handle my usual day-to-day tasks.

For everyday use, I need a web browser, Google Now, Spotify, YouTube, the Facebook home screen widget, and, during the baseball season, the MLB.com app and widget. I have a couple of young kids at home, so I want a camera that can adequately capture the cute things they do, especially under indoor lighting conditions. I look at my screen between 2 and 3 hours in a 14-hour day. I don't have much use for NFC or a fingerprint scanner.

The first stop in my phone-buying journey was purchasing this phone from a store near my house. I wanted to see if all the glowing reviews were true, and if I could live with a $179 phone after using flagships my whole smartphone-owning life. Long story short: I couldn't. The Moto G 3rd gen met my needs better than I expected it to, but not quite as well as I needed.

Good stuff abut this phone:

1. The software on the Moto G is very nearly stock Android, which suited me fine, even coming from the heavily-modified version I was using on the LG G2. The phone performed relatively quickly, and all my apps and widgets loaded fine. Set up was supremely easy, and the Moto Migrate software was a godsend. My contacts, apps, call logs, pictures, and SMS messages were sent over from the G2 in mere moments. I think I had the phone customized to my needs (including logging into all my apps) within 10 minutes, and it felt like I could walk out the door and not think about it again.

2. The Moto gestures (double twist for camera and double chop for flashlight) are AMAZING, though I'd prefer it if the flashlight stayed on after I set the phone down. I like to sometimes use my phone as a lantern in the bedroom when I'm getting in bed, instead of turning on a light.

3. The camera is tremendous... if you're outside with good natural light. Indoors under incandescents or fluorescents it's really poor. It launches quickly and does a good job with focus.

4. The size of the phone was perfect. Its dimensions are nearly identical to the LG G2, so it felt great in my hand and my pocket, and I pretty quickly adapted to the location of the buttons. It also uses a micro-SIM card, which meant I didn't have to go into a carrier store to get a new SIM just to use my phone.

Bad stuff about this phone:

1. My day-to-day use was apparently too much for the Moto G to handle. I'd have frequent app crashes, and widgets would fail to update—or even fail to load entirely. I think the 1 gig of RAM was too little for my needs, but I can't be sure that's all it was. There is also a noticeable lag to using this phone that I wasn't ready for. I never tried a 2 gig version, because I was loathe to order from Motorola directly, wait for the phone to arrive, and then ship it back to them if it didn't turn out well.

2. The camera indoors worked so poorly for my needs. It was slow to focus, and it produced images that were marred with tons of blur, coming out as yellow-tinted, blocky messes, even with all the lights in the house on. And the camera app is so dumbed down that it's less useful than it should be. Put a dang shutter button on the screen, Moto!

3. The battery charges sooooooo sloooowwwwwly. It took 4 hours to charge it, and it barely lasted the entire day on a charge. What gives?

My final verdict:

I couldn't make this phone usable for my needs. If you or someone you love needs an uncomplicated phone that can make calls, get them on the internet, handle Facebook and email fine, and take good pictures of flowers and trees and outside things, tell them to buy a Moto G. It would be a great phone for my mother in-law, but it didn't quite cut it for me.

As for my smartphone journey: I love Moto's customizations enough that I sacrificed my size requirement and ended up choosing a Moto X Pure, even after a two-week period where I compared it directly to the smaller LG Nexus 5X. For my money, the Moto X Pure is the best phone out right now—even with its similar indoor-camera issues—but I'm a little biased, because I had a 10% off coupon from BBY and got mine for $45 off the retail price.

I bought an SD card to expand storage but now with the update you have to choose between portable and external storage and if you choose "internal" you can no longer use the SD card in any other device, and you can no longer access the internal storage, so I don't want to make my SD card less useful, and if I don't format it for internal storage I can't move apps over to it. It seems like 8gb is just too low of memory for this phone. So I just ordered the bigger option (16gb & 2gb RAM) and am going to return this smaller one. I love the phone over all, but the internal memory is just too low to keep up with the constant Android OS and app updates that keep taking up more memory every time. I was trying to get a "future-proof" phone and for that it seems like 16gb internal memory is the minimum necessary for that. The 1gb of RAM in this version has been fine for me, I don't play games but tend to multitask using apps and several internet windows at once and I didn't notice any lag or problems until this new update took up way more of the internal storage available. I wish that Motorola offered the base product Moto G 3rd Gen with 16gb internal storage, it seems a bit tricky to put out a product that is cheaper but won't keep up with Android updates! Definitely shell-out the extra $40 if you are interested in getting a phone that will last!

I bought this phone directly from Motorola but wanted to write a review to encourage other Android enthusiasts to give this phone consideration. For the price, this phone's offerings are worth five stars. The 16 GB storage, 2 MB RAM version is almost as robust as similar phones on the market that cost $600+. My phone arrived with Android 6.0 Marshmallow installed. Functions and apps work smoothly; I did not detect a slower performance on this phone than my newly retired Samsung Galaxy S4. Camera takes good photos except in low light, but that's no different than the S4. The battery power is sufficient, though you simply cannot get a lot of battery power unless you are using a much larger phone (phablet) with a much larger battery. Leaving the phone idle for several hours does not drain the battery.

The two major difference I've noticed between this Moto G vs. other higher end phones are the display resolution is not as robust and the speaker sound is low quality. The phone outer body is built well and the "water resistant" feature is great if you drop your phone in water for a few seconds, but prevents you from being able to change out the battery. The SIM and SD card slots, however, are easy to access if you pull off the back cover. Having a SD card slow is a major plus for this phone, and one that many  manufacturers are moving away from so that they can charge you more money for cheap pre-installed memory.  The sound quality is not an issue for me as I connect my phone to Bluetooth devices when listening to music.

The front facing speaker on this one, similar to the HTC One, is an EXCELLENT design feature. Who listens to their phone from the back of the phone??? As far as I know, people look at their phones from the front and hold their phones with the front facing their ear while talking on the phone.

The button placements on the Moto G are also well thought out, as the volume up/down buttons and power button are both on the top right side edge of the phone. I didn't know this at the time, but Samsung placed opposable buttons on their S4 and I accidentally  hung up on people about 50% of the time because my index finger just happened to rest on that stupidly placed button while I was holding the phone.

I'm also really enthused about the lack of bloatware installed on this unlocked version as when I was a Verizon customer who installed such apps such as NFL on my phone that I could not uninstall, and which took up a lot of space on my phone's memory card. Unlocked is the way to go to avoid the bloatware from Verizon and AT&T.

Also I appload Moto for continuing to produce a phone that isn't a huge phablet; some customers like myself do not ever want a phablet sized phone, and my options in the market currently were very limited. Please continue to think of us consumers who have hands that are not as large as an NFL player's.

This phone has worked splendidly with Cricket Wireless's service. An unlocked phone will give you more options for service providers.

This phone is far ahead of the Galaxy S4 I just retired (except for display quality), and at a third of the price.

The Moto G is an excellent low-cost ($179 unlocked) smartphone running the latest version of Android (5.1). Just note that this version will not work with Verizon here in the United States.

What makes it excellent? It's the fact that it feels snappy and responsive, has decent battery life, and a better than expected camera. It will very easily meet the needs of most casual smartphone users for a price substantially less than that of some of the flagship phones on the market.

It's also waterproof up to 3 feet at 30 minutes. So it can be dropped in a sink or bathtub without any damage to the phone provided the backing is secured to the properly. I demonstrate the waterproofing in the video.

Motorola is taking a unique approach to the Android phone market by delivering good hardware at a low price without a carrier obligation. This phone most certainly is that - a sub $200 that will be more than adequate for most people in the market for a decent phone.

DISCLOSURE - Motorola provided me with a product sample at their recent press event for my YouTube channel.

I don't normally write a poor review but right now, I think it is necessary.

I purchased the Moto G 3rd gen phone not too long ago after reading tons of reviews and write ups and all sorts of raves about this phone.  There is one thing that I would have liked to know which is ESSENTIAL to me and if I had known this, I would not have purchased this phone.

Yes, this phone has nice screen, nice features, and works okay.  For the price it is decent, EXCEPT THERE IS NO HANDS FREE VOICE RECOGNITION FOR DRIVING BUILT INTO THIS PHONE.

I have had phones which are ARCHAIC compared to this phone that have had voice recognition.  That allows the phone to answer through a bluetooth device such as a speaker in the car.

I recently just discovered that the Moto Assist has been retired from the Marshmallow update so there are not any options for this phone to be used hands free while driving, so even the option that ate up data time is now gone.

That makes me very upset.

I could rave on about the other features of this phone, and perhaps to some of you that would be enough.  However, in my situation, when I am driving, I like to be able to talk via bluetooth speaker phone in the car and not rake up huge data bills.

Any other app that we have tried does not work right with this phone, either.

I will update this review should I find an acceptable solution to this problem and if I decide to keep the phone.  For now, I could care less about all of the fancy features of the phone when I can not use it for one of the essential tasks that I use constantly when driving.

UPDATE
I am waiting for something to change in Marshmallow, but I will take some time and update this review with my detailed observations of this phone as I continue to use it while NOT in the car driving.  Other than the problem which is an Android problem, not Motorola (although their program that used to work no longer does for that purpose) I have found the phone to be a very decent  budget phone compared to others I have used.

I will update soon as I can to reflect my other opinions on the phone.  I did want to warn people right away about the current situation in case they were depending on this phone to use for hands free driving to call and answer via bluetooth speakers.  If you have an older phone that will not update to Marshmallow, then you will probably be okay.  I would wait for an upgrade if your current phone works fine with your bluetooth speakers in the car at least to use it for your phone at this point.

I am coming from 1st Gen Moto X.  It takes a bit of time getting used to the new operating system and a lot of tweaking that has to be done after migrating my settings.  The biggest headache was the messaging notification Led light.  I had to download Flash Alerts 2 app by MegaWave Software and purchase it for a couple bucks to enable Application Filter (part of Status Bar Change within that program).  In setting the Application Filter, I checkmark messaging, phone, etc... that are important to a ring, vibrate, silent, etc...  If that program wasn't available, then the user would have to go through the hard way that could take more than 3 hours to figure it out and would void the warranty of the phone.  It's found in this article:  http://www.droidguiding.com/how-to-enable-hidden-led-notification-on-3rd-gen-moto-g-2015 (my phone wouldn't be recognized on Windows 10 but on a Windows 7 computer for "rooting" the phone.  I successfully rooted my Moto X phone with Windows 7 through Motorola website (will need your Motorola userID and pwd).  It's not an easy thing to do and I would leave that to the developers; in fact, you would also need to enable that phone as a developer phone, search online for that!

The camera is definitely a big improvement, I don't expect it to be great in low light settings but it's definitely a step up.  The screen is slightly bigger and helps on my eyes.  This thing fits in my pocket like a pocket knife.  It would be five stars if they had included led notification light in the settings of Google Lollipop 5.1.1.  The Internet speed is much faster on Verizon FIOS wireless.  Make sure you buy storage like 32GB MicroSD before using the phone.  The storage it has is like 4.5 Gb and I already used up 1/2 of it with all my apps installed.  When going into settings\storage\Apps (click on the Apps on that list, after Available).  Concentrate on the top 10, and open them all, Select "Move to SD Card" to move the data to the SD Card from the phone to save space.  People may not realize that this is how to save space on the primary phone.  If you have a ton of Apps on your current phone, I would NOT RECOMMEND this phone, just purchase one that is double the space, 16GB on the phone that is NOT SOLD on Amazon and has double the RAM (not sure it makes a difference for me since I had double the RAM on Moto X).

Hope all this helps!!!

May The Force Be With You.

After putting this off for a while, it finally happened. After over 3 years on the previous phone...a smaller Samsung...I finally pulled the trigger on a new phone. And I couldn't be more pleased. I researched this purchase for a while and the Moto G 3 kept showing up as the best value in the under $300 category..consistently over the last few months. I looked at the main competitors..the Sony Experia and the Asus Zen Phone, and really wasn't that impressed. It seemed that this one was the better choice for the average phone user. A power user might disagree, but that's not me.This is a great phone that has snappy performance and just plays well. It's not loaded with too much crap either. Yes, the camera is decent, but I do my photography with a real camera and it wasn't a deciding factor. Call quality is definitely better than my previous phone and has better tone through the speaker. Some would point out that they cut corners with the 720p screen. I would say here that, if they had to cut corners to offer some other feature, they did it in a good place. For the most part, you really don't notice that the screen res is not up to snuff with the big money phones. Get over it with the specs already! They're often used as a marketing tool. People have a thing about this stuff. They have to out-spec the neighbors and the marketing and sales guys love this. Here the 720p screen is fine. Nuff said. If you need a medium priced phone, this one that easily deserves looking at. And yes, the 2g/16g combo is worth the extra bucks.

i'm a big time motorola fan of late.  i've had a razr m, 2013 moto x,  2015 moto e and a 2015 moto X.  Still have the 2015 moto E which has the same cpu as the moto G (except 200 mhz slower) with 1GB ram instead of 2GB.  dropped my moto X and it shattered into pieces and got the 2015 moto G with 2GB ram.

now based on using the moto E i expected it to be relatively smooth but i wasn't sure if the 2GB of ram would be hugely better or just a little.  the moto E was a little slow sometimes starting / switching apps.  let me tell you ,  the 2GB of ram is absolutely worth the $40 extra (not to mention the 8GB more flash).  the phone feels nearly as smooth as the 2015 moto X for most typical apps (like chrome, facebook , instagram etc) and feels like a hugely better phone than the moto E (and the E isn't that bad).  its definitely around as fast as the 2013 moto X which was a flagship with probably 3 times the battery life and a much better camera.  the camera really isn't that much worse than the 2015 moto x .  i'd say this was the phone i should have bought in the first place as i normally don't like investing in flagship phones.  the X has much nicer speakers,  a nicer screen (though really it wasnt that big a deal for me) but its bigger and has probably 70% the battery life and costs twice as much and was a bit harder to hold (which is how i accidentally dropped it on to a concrete floor :( ).

anyway,  i'd just like to say this is probably one of the best bargains in android phone land out there.  i'm an android developer for my job, and have an S6 edge and nexus 5 and a few other test phones, and i still choose to buy THIS phone.  thats how great a value it is.  its everything you need and nothing you dont.  spend the money on other things!

I am no techie, but had two requirements for my next smart phone.  First, I needed an unlocked phone that would allow me to switch and/or install two SIM cards and work on European LTE networks because that's where I spend months at a time. Next, since neither my professional or personal identity depends on what cell phone I use, I was not willing to spend oodles of mone, but at the same time wanted functionality, quality, and reliability.  Moto G 3rd Gen has met my objectives and then some. I've had the phone for about two months now. I am not a heavy user and don't live my life attached to social networks.  I make and receive maybe twenty calls a day; send and receive about the same number of texts;  check, write and send any number of e-mails; use a few aps - banking, weather, calendar & notifications, memos & schedules, etc; google a few things; check Twitter; take and send a couple of photos a day; and that about does it.  Battery life is excellent and with an overnight charge, I've had no worries.  Speaker sound is also really crips.  Photos are as good as from any other phone. The phone looks and feels very solid and smooth, and while it's not an S6, for under $180 that I spent on the white model, I have no complaints.  Actually I do.  So far there has been no accessories for this newer 3rd Gen release.  It's like what Motorola offers is pretty much what you get.

This is the best Android phone I've owned to date, and I've owned newer phones than this. This phone has fantastic battery life--on par or better than my Sony Xperia Z3C, which itself had a relatively enormous battery. With light use, I can get a full 2 days out of the phone, which is very important to me.

I also wanted a phone with the least amount of Android modification. I hate the bloatware and restyling of the Samsung phones, for example. For that reason I was strongly leaning toward a Nexus device. In the end I settled on this phone, as it had a smaller form factor than the Nexus devices, better battery life, and much better value. It also runs the latest Android 6.0, like the Nexus devices, and has minimal manufacturer bloatware. In fact, the few Motorola features that I notice are well integrated and actually improve the product: twisting the phone twice to activate the camera, and "chopping" the phone to turn on the light. I love these features and use them regularly.

If you buy the 8GB version, adding an external SD card will STILL result in issues around storage space.

This is bc even in Android Marshmallow, external SD cards considered "adoptable storage" or "internal storage" do not actually function this way. There is still a difference between internal storage and SD card storage, and app developers can stipulate that their app must be on internal storage.

Thus, many apps may not be on the SD card, and you will still run into "insufficient storage" issues when trying to install new apps.

After my old phone gave up the ghost, I picked up a Moto G.  It seemed to tick all of the right boxes - 1) micro SD, 2) decent CPU / RAM, 3) great battery life and 4) a decent camera.

There was some issues with the phone, but in general, I had no complaint - it's a phone that is more than the sum of its parts.  Build quality, thoughtfulness and lack of bloatware add up to the best phone in its price range.

Now, the bad news . . . less than a month after I bought the phone, I started receiving more and more frequent "Micro SD Card Unexpectedly Unmounted" error messages.  I tried multiple micro SD cards, but all of them would soon fail within minutes.

I went to Motorola's website and sent in my unit for "repair".  It turns out that Motorola does NOT repair Moto Gs.  It holds them until it has a sufficient supply of refurbished phones in stock, which may take MONTHS.

Each time I called customer support, I was constantly told that my phone would be returned "in a few days".  It turns out that the lower tiers of customer service have no decision making authority - after a MONTH, I was placed into "escalated customer service".  The representative explained that they did not have any Moto Gs "in stock for replacement service" and they do not repair Moto Gs.  They had no clarity on when they would have phones in stock and I only had two options - wait for an unknown amount of time, accept a worse phone or return my broken phone.

As a result, I would sincerely caution any prospective buyer - it's a great phone, but the warranty is in name only.  Be careful that you do not send this phone in for repair - better to go to a third party and pay out of pocket.  Online searches after the fact revealed this is unfortunately not an isolated issue - Motorola has really cut down on their customer service for Moto Gs.

Super fast phone. I was able to transfer everything from my old phone using google play. I got this phone as an 'upgrade' from my 1st gen Moto G 4g. Performance is about the same between the two. So is battery life. I always install CyanogenMod on my phones, but the stock software is OK. An upgrade for this phone is obviously the camera, definetly better than my last one, but it show a lot of noise on indoor shots.

Here's why I went back to my 1st Gen.
This phone is too bulky, heavy, and big for what it is. I cannot figure out why a plastic 5" budget phone with low end specs, and minimal features is this heavy. Another thing I missed is the LED notification.

Motorola's way of making sales is the "one step forward, two step back" approach. I.E the very first moto g only had 3g and no SD slot, then a revised version came out with 4g and a SD slot. Same thing with the second generation with 3g/4g. Now Motorola removed the notification LED, and I'm willing to bet it will be added to the 'new' Moto 3rd gen.

I won't say its a horrible phone. But its a very mediocre 'OK' phone. Nothing groundbreaking like the first gen, with even less features and a bigger heavier design.

Never plug your phone into an untested charger that's not made by the OEM. I learned the hard way when I plugged my phone into a newly bought charger (my wife bought it in an effort to get rid of the rat's nest of wires on the charging desk --- needless to say it's the most expensive charger she's ever bought --- lesson: keep your rats nest and stick with well-reviewed chargers). Well, my Xperia Z1's motherboard got fried, and I had to shop for a new phone in a hurry.

I liked the Xperia Z1, so my initial thought was to just simply purchase an Xperia Z3. Alas, the price I got from Amazon did turn out to be too good to be true. Upon receiving the phone, I checked it against Sony's website and discovered that the "new" phone I was sold only had 2 months of warranty left. In other words, some reseller had bought the phone from Sony or T-mobile, and was reselling it to me as "new." The full price of the phone ($550) was more than I could stomach, so I went looking for other choices.

My criteria were:
Waterproof: having learned from the Xperia Z1 how useful a feature that was, I wasn't willing to give this up.
MicroSD card storage. Sorry, I'm not paying $100 to get an extra 16GB of storage. That's for Apple users. (I paid $25 for a 64GB MicroSD card)
2GB of RAM, preferably 3.
5" screen. More than that, and it's too awkward to hold one-handed.
Camera shutter button preferred.
Cheap. Let's face it, phone processor performance hasn't improved in years
Not surprisingly, other than the Xperia Z series, there are only a few phones that offer the first feature:
Sony M4 Aqua ($250)
Motorola Moto G ($220)
Samsung Galaxy S5 ($400)
The Samsung was too much to pay for, and I never liked the UI, so it came down to the Sony Aqua and the Moto G. I honestly did not expect the Moto G to be a contender, but since Lenovo acquired them from Google, Motorola has finally put microSD card storage even into its high end phones like the Moto X. Back when Google owned Motorola, it suffered from severe Apple envy and thought it could charge Apple-type prices for storage. The addition of waterproofing was a nice surprise. In fact, the higher-end phones in Motorola's line up all only have water-resistance, rather than being IP7 waterproof. I would have considered the shatter-proof Droid Turbo 2 if it had included water-proofing along with the 4 year anti-crack warranty. As it was, I figured I could get 3 Moto Gs for the price of one of those, and waterproofing trumps crack-proofing.

My experience with the Sony Z1 was that I was constantly getting applications killed. I'd play music and turn on navigation and music would die. I've also had the reverse happen. That made me wary of getting another Sony phone with just 2GB of RAM. (For whatever reason, this doesn't happen to my wife's Xperia Ultra Z, which at 6.5" in size is so big that it also has wonderful voice and data reception!)

Reviews consistently state that the Moto G has a better camera (surprising, since the Moto G's camera is a Sony sensor). The Sony M4 Aqua also has a faster processor, NFC, supports up to 128GB of microSD storage and is thinner. Both phones are 720p 5" displays, which is fine. What's interesting is that the Moto G did support my 64GB SD card, despite not being officially in the specs. I did have to reformat it with the phone, but after that it worked just great. It's unusual for companies to under promise and over-deliver, so I wonder what's going on there.

In practice, however, the Moto G actually appears faster than the M4 Aqua, even in the 1GB configuration! In the end, between the camera and improved performance, I went with the Moto G. Later research showed that the Snapdragon 615 used in the M4 Aqua has severe throttling issues due to overheating, so I unwittingly dodged a bullet.

Since I was buying in a hurry to replace a dead phone, I ordered the black version from Amazon rather than going through Moto Maker. It's also much easier to return something to Amazon than to Motorola, so that was a consideration.

The phone itself is fast, as fast as the Xperia Z1. Installing software, starting up software all felt faster than the Z1 (undoubtedly helped by not having to push as many pixels), while task switching was surprisingly quick with no latency experienced. The camera was about as fast as the Z1's, though obviously picture quality isn't anywhere close to the benchmark set by that camera. The twist to shoot gesture is a nice gimmick, and I thought it to be useless but to my surprise after a few days with the phone I could shoot with the camera while cycling! Video is surprisingly good:

By far the biggest issue with the phone is sluggish bluetooth pairing. In fact, for both my cars and the SBH52, I had to reboot the phone in order to do a pairing. Neither the Logitech X100 nor my vivoactive (which unfortunately needed a factory reset to unstick its pairing from the Z1) needed such a reboot. Once paired, the pairing sticks, so at least this is only a one time problem.

Sound quality is, not surprisingly, lacking compared to the Z1, but not so much so that I found it objectionable. Some have reported annoying cross-talk when plugging in headphones into the microphone jack. I was prepared to have to do without (most of my listening is via blue-tooth over the SBH52 anyway), but when I plugged in headphones it sounded just fine.

To my surprise, going from the Z1's 1080p screen down to the 720p screen didn't bother me at all. Of course, watching movies on the Z1 has always drained the battery so fast that I rarely did it, and in any case to save storage I'd always watched movies in 720p.

Motorola is well known for providing a near-stock Android experience with no additional UI tweaks. I didn't expect this to make a big difference to me, but it does and is a pleasant welcome after the Sony modifications to the OS. I also expect that this also contributed largely to the higher performance of the UI and software despite the supposedly slower processor.

After my experience with the Z1, which begged to be recharged nearly all the time, so much so that I put the phone into stamina mode full time, any change had to be better. The Moto G was disappointing at first, barely lasting  12 hours without a charge. But 2 charge cycles later the battery life improved dramatically, with me typically ending the day somewhere around 40-50% of battery life. On a heavy use day it'd drop to 15%. This is a huge improvement over the Xperia Z1, and makes use of say, the Garmin Livetrack feature much more feasible than before. With the Xperia Z1, even with stamina mode, I was unlikely to make it to the end of the day without a mid-day recharge. Lithium ion batteries will generally lose 20% of their capacity after 300 recharge cycles. If your battery is barely able to get you through the day, after a year, your battery will absolutely not get you through the day. And yes, this applies even if you're the type to keep it plugged in as often as possible. The relatively long battery life of the Moto G means that you can expect to get at least 2 years of use out of the phone before the non-replaceable battery starts to lose enough charge capacity to be annoying.

All in all, given the price of the phone and the features (waterproofing is huge for me), the performance of the phone is such that I will be happy to hang on to it for a good long time. I expect that if you manage to buy this phone during the inevitable black friday sales, you'll get it for a significant discount which will be an even better deal.

December 15, 2015

On November 22, 2015 Rita and I bought 2 Moto G cell phones from Amazon.com.  During the last three weeks we have been using these new phones on the Ting Cell Phone service network.  We decided on buying these phones based on the excellent reviews on Amazon.  There was one excellent review with a Youtube link where the reviewer showed the water resistant capabilities of the phone by dropping it in a bowl of water while playing a Youtube video.  Needless to say the phone still worked and continued to play the video while in the water.
I was surprised when I loaded a sshd server on the phone along with termux when I saw the amount of security that is incorporated with the Android OS.
Moto G Security Features

SE Linux
SE Linux is Security Enhanced Linux developed by the NSA.  SE Linux is one of the security tools that is excruciatingly hard to set up properly. Once it is set up it makes the system virtually impregnable to attack.  I was happily surprised that even when I logged in over ssh as root, I was not the root user.  I started to look around the /etc directory and saw properly configured SE Linux files.

Encrypt Cell Phone
There is a security feature that enables you to encrypt the entire cell phone which is the same as encrypting your hard drive or selected partitions.  This feature makes turning on your cell phone a little harder since you have to enter a password/phrase to boot the phone.  I'm a strong believer in encrypted drives and partitions and the use of AES-256 is pretty good encryption.

Features:
Camera with front and back lenses
Flashlight
Pre-installed google apps including
  Google plus
  G Mail
  Chrome Web Browser
Voice recognition opens with, “OK Google.”

This is a great phone that is a great buy for about $175.00 on Amazon.  Rita has told me several times that she loves her new phone.  I have added signal by Whisper Systems, Gnu Privacy Guard, and Rsync Backup to both phones so that I can backup both phones and have secure encrypted communications.  I would recommend for anyone looking for a new phone to buy this one.
  Have a great day
  Rev. LeRoy D. Cressy

I’ve been looking to replace my nearly 23 month old Nexus 5 for some time as the battery life was progressively declining. I considered opening up my Nexus 5, unscrewing things and getting a new battery, but had held off waiting for what the Nexus 5X would bring. In the meantime, I went on a questionably unsafe hike where it then poured and my Nexus 5 got more than a little wet. Needless to say, I needed a new phone as my Nexus 5 now had more than battery issues.

I settled on the Moto G 2015 16GB, 2GB RAM version directly from Motorola. Motorola lets you custom design your phone with multiple color choices, storage, engraving, etc. I went with a white face, blue back and champagne metal accent. Easier to find I figure than my old black rectangles. Designing is simple and easy and the changes update real time with a 360 rotation.

Ordering the Moto G was a snap, and in less than a week I had my Moto G in hand.

SHINY EXTERIOR (or not really):

The Moto G 2015 sports a 5” gorilla glass screen at a 1280 x 720 resolution for a 294 PPI. This is quite low compared to other phones out there, but the Moto G is also 33% or 50% of their price. Furthermore, higher resolutions require more powerful chips to run and suck up more power. Part of the reason I went with the Moto G over waiting for the Nexus 5X is because the Nexus 5X is rumored to have an even higher PPI than the Nexus 5 resulting in likely worse battery life. I can tell the difference between the Moto G and the Nexus 5 screens if I look real hard, but it doesn’t bother me. Screen to body ratio, or how much of the face is screen vs non-screen is 67%. Edge to edge screen this phone is not.

Now the back is way different from my Nexus 5 in that it’s textured and easy to grip unlike the smooth backing of the Nexus 5. Still plastic, but I don’t see a problem with that at all. The texture however is likely to accumulate all kinds of gunk and dust, so I’m putting mine in a case as soon as it arrives. The backing comes off revealing a micro SIM and MicroSD ports. You can order additional different color backings directly from Motorola to customize your phone and change the colors based on whatever you feel like.

The phone’s backing is curved with the audio port on the top. The top of the phone also curves down making audio port buttons like the Pressy PB01 The Android Smart Button Compatible with Galaxy, HTC, and Nexus Smartphones, Black not viable.

Power button is on the right above the volume up and down. Speaker (unknown if mono or stereo at this time) and microphone are front facing with respectable sound. Front facing with along with a 5 MP at f/2.2. The back camera is a 13 MP at f/2.0 with dual flash.

Weight is fairly average at 5.5 oz.

There is no notification light. So the ability to glance at your phone and see whether an email, text message, Facebook post, Instagram post or anything you’ve assigned an LED light color is flashing is now gone. In its place, the screen will now selectively turn on a small portion of the screen with the icon of the application when a notification comes in. Not as useful by far, but still better than nothing.

GUTS, WIRES, & SILICON:

The Moto G is running a quad core Qualcomm S410 which is a fairly low to midgrade processor with a Adreno 306 graphics chip. The S410 is actually quite a big improvement over the S400 despite being granted just 10 higher in the naming nomenclature. The S410 uses 64 Bit computing, is a quadcore vs dual core, better efficiency and uses ARM v8 which is a superior instruction set. Basically, don’t be fooled by the low processor number, this processor can handle most peoples’ daily routine. Don’t expect to run mobile high performance games at max here, but this will easily handle mundane tasks. Furthermore, remember, low to midgrade processors tend to be more power efficient leading to, you guessed it, better battery life.

Depending on the model you get, it will either be the 16GB/2GB Ram model or 8GB/1GB Ram model. I strongly suggest getting the 16GB/2GB Ram model. The 16GB model only had 11.81 GB free after OS. Android doesn't run all that well under load with just 1 GB of Ram.

Battery is rated at 2,470 mAh and is fairly impressive in how long it takes to drain the battery. With a lower resolution screen and a low to midgrade processor, the battery life on a sub 3,000 mAh battery phone is very impressive. Battery is NOT removable. After extended use of this phone, two days is plausible if you aren't a big movie or game player. I get up at 6:30 in the morning and after checking email, Facebook and a few other apps, my phone is down to 95% by 9:00 am. Finishing my day at 5:00 has my phone down to 83% despite usage all through the day. Turning into bed at 10:00 pm has the phone down to 68%. I can go two days without a recharge, but I'm also not streaming video or playing games. Your mileage will of course vary. The reviews aren’t kidding about “all day battery.” See my screenshot for more information. 31% usage on 15 hours with frequent, but short usage.

As usual, there is the standard Bluetooth, WiFi and GPS/GLONASS. iFixit hasn’t done a teardown of the 2015 Moto G, so I cannot be sure who’s making what chip. Odds are though it’s Broadcom providing the Bluetooth/GPS chip. There is NO NFC. I found that I rarely used NFC on my Nexus 5, so not a big deal to me. There’s an accelerometer and the regular gambit of sensors. There is however an FM radio that doesn’t rely on WiFi or a data plan. It does however require you to plug in headphones as they act as the antenna.

The specification page says that the phone works with microSD cards up to 32GB. This is inaccurate. I currently have a 64GB microSD card working perfectly with over 30 GB of music on it. You will need to have the phone format the microSD card first before you can start moving files on to it. The Moto G 2015 apparently only reads FAT32 format which Windows will not format a larger than 32GB memory card to. Motorola I believe stated that up to 32GB as some larger cards may perform inconsistently.  See my photo for more information.

THE DIGITAL BITS, SOFTWARE:

Motorola has adopted stock Android+, where the + is a few optional Motorola apps which are relatively useful. There is no Samsung Touchwiz, or LG, HTC or other manufacture skin on the phone that so regularly slows down devices running such skins. So if you like stock android, this is a huge benefit, out of the box virtually stock Android. My model shipped with Android 5.1 Lollipop. You get to decide what your phone looks like, the power is yours.

Motorola has included a few Motorola apps which are pretty useful in learning your routine to keeping the screen off during your regular sleep hours, what to do based on certain motions of the phone, who’s calls and text messages to block and let through based on your calendar and so on and so forth. The best thing is that none of these are mandatory and you can completely ignore them should you wish to. It’s all up to you.

USB OTG is enabled, but you do need a third party software package like the Nexus Media Importer application to read USB hard drives and flash drives. Mice work without any additional software. The microUSB port will not however connect through a wired CAT5 adapter to the internet (or at least mine didn’t play nice).

If you’ve previously been on an Android phone, the transfer is super simple via either the built in app “migrate” or by Google’s cloud backup. The real nice software bit is that you don’t have to install every Google App in this process. Don’t want Google Keep/Wallet/Etc? Don’t install it.

CONNECTIVITY:

The phone will work with GSM and CDMA carriers, which includes all of the four major carriers in the US and their subsidiaries.

Be aware T-Mobile and other GSM buyers, if you order directly from Motorola, you’ll get the XT1540 model which DOES NOT HAVE BAND 12. That band is required for voLTE which is a higher bandwidth form of data. Regular LTE and HSPA+ are supported. The CDMA version does have band 12 but lacks many of the bands to access GSM carrier frequencies.

LOOK MA, I'M A PHOTOGRAPHER, THE CAMERA:

The camera is a 13 megapixel at f/2.0 with dual flash with a front facing camera at 5 MP at f/2.2. Low light shots are mediocre at best, but well to moderately lit environments has the camera performing at a $500 smartphone level (see photo). Autofocus is reasonably fast and flash is bright.

Stock software includes HDR, Panoramic, video recording as well as built in a QR/bar code reading software. There is no image stabilization software which may create some blurry photos, but you may be able to find some camera software app that can mitigate that.

Considering that this phone costs $179 for the 8GB/1 GB Ram model and $219 for the 16GB/2 GB Ram model, the camera is beyond expectations.

OH CRAP I DROPPED IT IN WATER, OH YEAH IT'S WATER RESISTANT:

It’s amazing that a $179-219 phone is shipping with IPX7, which allows for 30 minutes submersion in fresh water without damage. How many people themselves or know someone who has damaged a smartphone by getting it wet? I’m guessing nearly everyone. With the Moto G 2015, you can carry on like normal when it rains, not freak out when someone spills a drink, and wash your phone under the faucet should it get dirty. Why can’t every brand follow Motorola on this?

NOW FOR SOME CELL PHONE PHILOSOPHY:

This phone is rock bottom cheap. But it’s not $199? Guess what? Phones selling for$199 never cost $199. They were really $500+ and $649 phones being sold at $199 with contract were in reality over 24 months well over $700. The $199 iPhone is a myth designed to sucker people into buying a phone and paying more than retail for it. John Ledger at T-Mobile bust this myth open and everyone is following him.

Now, the question is, will this budget phone do the job? Ask yourself, what do you primarily do on your phone? Text? Calls? Email? Browsing? Youtube? WeChat? Amazon? Facebook? Candy Crush? Tweet? Instagram? If you answered yes to any of those, this phone is for you. Why spend $649 on a high powered phone that you will not use the capabilities of? Save that $430 and spend in something you will like gas, rent, food, etc. Or even better, invest it and when you need a new phone, buy it with the earnings from your $430 investment.

Buy smart, and buy what you need and what you’ll actually use. And odds are, this phone will fit your needs just right at an absurdly low price.

TLDR:

Pros: Cheap, awesome battery life, decent camera, water resistant, back plate customization and microSD card

Cons: No voLTE, no notification light, no NFC, no removable battery, midgrade resolution and midgrade performance

So I have been using the Moto G 2015 for a month now and thought that I would make a review for the same.Here is a short summary of my review which can be found on youtube here https://youtu.be/Zxvkvzr1OPk
Pros:-
1.Stock Android:- Very smooth and snappy on the Moto G.The animations are very smooth and there's barely any lag or stutter while using the phone on daily basis.
2.Updates:-Motorola has always been great with updates and even this time, the Moto G 2015 should get the Android 6.0 Update soon after the official launch
3.Amazing Battery Life:- I could easily touch 5 hours of screen on time with AutoSync On, Wifi On, Bluetooth On(with my Moto 360).On a heavy day with 3G data and no wifi, I could still get more then 4 hours of Screen on time over a 13-15 hour long day.Even my LG G4 or the Galaxy S6 cannot touch this type of battery life on my normal usage.
4.Decent internals:-The Snapdragon 410 and 2GB of RAM do a great job when it comes to daily use and multitasking.I could play most of the games on the phone without any issues and overall, for $200, You can't ask for more.
5.Expandable Storage:- This is a huge plus on the device as you can add upto 32GB of Memory Card along with the 16GB of internal storage
6.4G LTE and Dual SIM
Cons:-
1.Camera:- While decent in daylight,The low light performance is poor and the Motorola Camera app is something that I don't like that much
2.Display:-The 720p IPS Panel is not that sharp and crispy and contrast/color reproduction is poor too.But at this price point, I think this is fine

Overall, at this price point,The Moto G 2015 is a great buy.For more in depth coverage,including camera samples, Do watch my full review of the phone here:-http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Zxvkvzr1OPk

The 2nd phone didn't connect either. After doing my own online research and talking to 2 more Motorola agents, they finally admitted MOTOROLA DOES NOT MAKE A GLOBAL GSM UNLOCKED MOTO G 3!

In the midst of this disastrous customer experience, AMAZON on the other hand has been AMAZING! They actually shipped me another phone and when they heard it is useless to me, offered to refund me completely.

However, the phone itself is great, if you live in the USA. After owning 2 MOTO G 2nd gens, I was thrilled to get this latest version with upgrades and improvements AT THE SAME PRICE. The phone is well -built, feels solid and comfortable in my hand, it's super-attractive (now with the optional custom build), has a much improved camera over MOTO G 2 (which I also loved) and now has the all-important water-resistance (which I have not had occasiont to test). This phone is more a compromise than anything else.
After almost 4 years I decided to ditch my S3 for a new unlocked phone. I am grandfathered with AT&T with a low cost plan and given the rip off for new smartphones now imposed by the carriers better get a generic unlocked phone. The deal was quite attractive also.
Don't get me wrong there are a lot of good things about this phone and Android 5.1.1. It is fairly fast and the screen resolution while low is adequate for most common usage, but if you are a casual user like me, on the lazy side when it comes to configuring a phone, you are up for a bad surprise.
So after more than a week of tinkering with it, here are the things that may or may not turn you off.
1. Power button: it is small and on the side. You'll have to use it all the time to awake your phone which is just a terrible annoyance. I tried many of the double tap/gyroscopic apps to alleviate that issue but nothing really gives you the ease of having just a front button like the premium brands.
2. Android 5.1.1 is a very "basic" product on that phone, and you'll have to spend hours reconfiguring it to get close to what you could have with a premium brand phone. Quite honestly most of the redesigned apps like mail, calendar, clock, Music, Camera... suck. Examples: you cannot use a mp3 file as your awakening music with the Alarm app. The old eMail program is gone replaced by the Google Gmail app which does not provide you with a clear view of your email accounts when all combined (you cannot figure out which email belongs to what account), there is also no mass selection and deletion. You cannot have a year view in your calendar, you need to flip through every single month (huh!). There is no decent weather widget. Google play cannot open on My Library and the standard playlist are just dumb lists without real sorting options. There are very limited ringtones and notification sounds, etc...you go the picture. All that to say that you are going to spend a lot of time downloading better apps, if you can find ones, to address these issues.
3. this is not a slim phone, but this is probably due to a more powerful battery...that you cannot change !
4. the phone is difficult (almost impossible) to read outside in bright light.

Now there are things that I like:
- being able to act on email and messages from the Notifications drop-down. This is real a plus!
- the dreamscreen that shows you key notification info without having to unlock the phone.
- Battery life is pretty good. But this is just the beginning and they are usually always good for the first month or so.

Now, I will probably keep it because it was cheap, did not change my contract and because I am not a intensive user of it.
But beware of the limitations.

UPDATE:

Bought this for my wife and then went on a 4 month deployment. She used it for a total of 7 months now. This review is only for the quality of the phone as I have not played around with it too much.

 I have an HTC One M8 that is 90% all metal so that is where my expectations are.

Quality: Aside that it is a plastic cased phone, the plastic has held up exceptional. I would put it on par with more expensive iPhone and Samsung devices. The glass has no shields on it and has absolutely no scratches. This is surprising to me as my wife typically throws her phone in her purse unguarded against foreign sharp objects. She uses her phone a lot, and also lets our 4 year old use it as well. Anyone with 4 year olds know that they have a tendency to randomly throw phones when they do not do what they want them to do.

The back shell has never fallen off... something I have seen Samsung phones do.

The SD card is still working well inside the phone. Phone still works buttery smooth... I am a little jealous because, at times, my HTC gets bogged down... then again, I am an app happy android fanboy.

Sound is actually really loud. I have the HTC boom speakers on my phone, and while the Moto G does not have dual surround sound speakers, they are almost as loud as mine... and do not sound all that bad.

I would buy this again!

This phone has built in WiFi and I am able to use it as a full blown smart phone, except I don't have the $45 / month data plan charges.  The other thing that I have discovered is that when I am away from home, there are free hot spots just about everywhere, so I have had no problems using as a smart phone when out and about.  Another nice thing I discovered it that I have Cox Cable for my home ISP. I have had many cell phones in my life but I can honestly say that this is the best one yet!!!  I ordered it directly from Motorola and it came in about five days. It was seamless to set up.  What I absolutely love about this phone is that I live a very active lifestyle, and it is so durable (yeah I dropped it the first day I owned it.  Twice. Everything still in tact!). I had a few iPhones and Samsungs and I got tired of watching their batteries drain and their screens shatter when dropped....enough.  Time for something different.

More importantly for me:  I can use this phone all day long and not even have to charge it once!  The battery life for this phone is absolutely stellar!!!!!  The camera is good too...taken it hiking, even in misty rain, and it held up perfectly.  Of course I am definitely not going to dunk it in water for 30 minutes ... but I was pleased that the misty moisture didn't ruin the phone.

Dollar for dollar I don't think this phone can be beat. I paid less than 200 ... a third of what an iPhone costs!!!.. I was with Straighttalk Wireless, but switched to Cricket (AT&T) for $35.00 a month autopay when I bought this phone so I'll save 15 bucks each month! I don't use a cell phone much so maybe my strategy won't help many people, but I only pay $3 a month for phone service with H2O. Add to that the cost of an unlocked Moto G and It works out to $18 a month for one year.

I'm sure some people have to have a constant connection, but I'd rather have my $$ at the end of the month!

I bought this phone (16GB version) to replace my crappy ZTE Overture 2 that I got when I switched to Cricket wireless. The main reason I bought this phone was because so many websites was calling it the best phone for under $200. Problem was it sold out so fast and when it finally came back in stock Motorola's website (where you could customize your phone) wouldn't work half the time. Also, no longer was the phone $180 before taxes but $219 on Amazon which meant the phone ended up $230 by the time I hit checkout. Probably could have been patient and waited for one at a lower price but didn't want to risk it selling out again.

What I like most about this phone is several things. The 5 inch 720p screen is really nice for watching HD movies. The lake of practically any bloatware is a godsend and therefore feels like you really get the most out of the 16GB than you would with any carrier phone. Speaking of which I love how it's unlocked. Right now Cricket wireless probably has the best plans you can get when you consider their prices and the fact they use AT&T's network, however they're phones are horrible so this allows me to enjoy both worlds. That said, now that T-Mobile is allowing unlimited Pandora streaming and rumor has it soon unlimited Netflix streaming, I can switch over to them if I wanted and still use this great phone. Performance wise, this thing hasn't slow down or froze yet (Again keep in mind I have the 16GB with 2GB memory). I'll admit I pretty much use it only for phone calls, internet browsing, video watching, and navigation, but the few games I do have install on it run flawlessly (mostly old Nintendo/Sega games). The camera is fantastic during the day but does suffer in the dark. I also find Motorola's camera program not as easy to use as ZTE's or Samsung's. Battery life is not bad. Heavy use I get about a day out of it. Little use, three days. Finally I also like how I can expect to get some mileage from this phone at Motorola is claiming that it will support Android 6.0 Marshmallow once it comes out.

Overall I'm pretty happy with this phone but the recent price hike does hurt it's value. If you can get it for any price cheaper I say jump on it.

I have never seen a new phone run so slowly. Apps take up to thirty seconds to open, crash frequently, and even the keyboard types painfully slowly. This phone has such poor connectivity with other devices, such as the wifi on my camera, that I can't even use the two together. It even seems to have deteriorated in the one week I've been using it. It's absolutely worth paying double the price for a decent phone. I would return the phone in an instant, but due to traveling circumstances, the return window has passed.

I have owned this phone for a little over a month so I am now updating this review to reflect my experience:

During the past month and a half I have used this phone (16gb/2 gig ram model) as my daily driver. It has a multitude of applications now installed - I use it for phone calls, emails, text messages, media streaming, social networking, etc...
THIS PHONE DOES NOT SLOW DOWN. You heard me right! I previously owned the Moto G (1st Gen LTE) and became frustrated after a few weeks as it became sluggish and weighed down either by multiple applications being open or an application that took up a lot of memory. This model... nope. It runs like butter!
The screen, while 720p, does a great job and looks good. It is not Samsung S6 quality, but then again, you are not paying an S6 price tag... I will live with the compromise.
The front-facing speaker is loud and clear. The touch screen is very responsive. The camera takes excellent pictures with good lighting; get it in really low light environments and you may struggle for a good, clear shot.
All-in-all you are getting an excellent phone for the price. Hell, you are just getting an excellent phone.
I have been an iPhone 5c in the past and really would say this phone is comparable. It is plastic but packs a high-end experience. It has a clean, simple interface. It is not bogged down by bloatware or useless gimmicks. You end up with a very reliable, sturdy phone that just works so damn well.
Enjoy this phone but I would encourage you to splurge the extra $40 on Motorola.com for the 2gb model.

SHORT VERSION: This is a good disposable phone.  If you have a problem with it, dispose it and buy another (they'll love you for it-or better yet buy something else).  I had an issue, and sent it for factory warranty.  Moto Care says they will send a replacement "like new" phone.  They keep saying "very soon".  I have been waiting over two months.

LONG VERSION: Last summer, I switched from Verizon to Tmobile.  I bought two LG phones at the tmobile store-an optimus L90 and a Leon.  They work well, but I wanted something with a good camera and a screen that I could see in the daylight.  I noticed that the LG phones (8GB) filled up quickly, even though we don't use many apps.  I believe the Google apps are to blame for that.

So I found the Moto G and was impressed by the specs for the price (I refuse to pay laptop prices for a phone that is carried daily).  The only place I found a 16 GB version was on the Motorola website.  Ordered and waited 2-3 weeks.  Received in August 2015.  I am giving this 2 stars instead of 1 because I really liked the phone before it fell apart.  It worked perfectly, and I was reassured by the waterproof feature.  Around the mid-December the plastic trim piece surrounding the back camera lens came unglued.  I thought about fixing it myself, and thought well at four months the factory warranty should cover it.

I went to the Moto website and chose the return option (didn't want to throw good money after bad with exchange).  I sent it in Jan 4 and received an email with a RMA number and tracking website.  After two weeks, still no status changes per website.  I decide to call and was told they are waiting on a shipment.  Three additional calls over the following two weeks with the same story.  After a month I was escalated, but the story was the same.  They could not repair it, or replace it.  I asked for my phone to be shipped back unrepaired.  THEY COULDN'T DO THAT EITHER!  The rep informed me that they can offer a 8GB phone to use while I wait for the shipment.

UPDATE: I was offered a 16 GB phone three days after I got the 8 GB.  So I sent it back.  Didn't want to pay for expedite (mainly on principle-but I wonder if that is the best way to go).  So they will not send the replacement phone until they get return.

 I have waited 2 months for a working equivalent phone.  I have wasted $60 in service from Tmobile during this wait.  I would never have guessed that, when I dropped my phone to Fedex before Jan 1, I would still be waiting for a replacement in March.

It would seem that Motorola is standing behind their product.  And I do appreciate that calling customer service yields minimal hold time and minimal talking to a computer.  I have called in a dozen times and spend around two hours on the phone with them.  But at this point, I feel like I sent my moto g into a black hole.  I know this is a tough market, and the value on this phone is amazing.  But I am not ready to accept that a $220 phone is disposable.  Maybe it's just me...

UPDATE FOR APRIL FOOLS
I just got off the phone with customer service.  All this time and I never thought to ask for the supervisor of the escalation team.  Doesn't matter the answer is the same.  No phones to ship out.  Estimate 1-2 weeks.  That puts me at April fools or the week after for a phone I sent in last year.  I am the fool.

I did not want to admit defeat, but they got me.  I feel they should stand behind the product if they say there is a warranty.  There is no warranty.  Just smoke and mirrors.  They will steal your phone if you like.  I don't really have the money to buy another phone.  But that is what I am going to do.  I honestly don't believe they are going to ship me anything.  If they do, my confidence is zero that I can rely on such a shoddy product.

Please do not support this company.  My experience is real and it could happen to you.

Bought this phone back in August. Some websites did not show correctly and performance on those sites were very slow. I later realized that the color depth (number of individual colors displayed) is extremely low on ALL websites (looks like 256 in contrast to the usual 16.7 million). It's not the screen but some kind software issue or other hardware limitation that I only experienced on the G 3rd generation. All Moto G 2nd generation are fine.
I contacted Motorola support to see if this is only true for my particular device or if it's the same for all devices. It took me endless chats, emails, screenshots and phone calls. I was forced by the service to do software updates and factory resets. Now, way over 4 weeks of back and forth they acknowledge that it's an issue with all of the phones. But they don't have a resolution. Actually I was just told that they will look into the fact if this issue needs to be resolved or if it's just within specs. What the crap. DON'T BUY THIS PHONE.

I haven't tried the water resistance part yet, so I cannot comment on that. My only concern is the battery. Only had it for a few months, and when I use it heavily (GPS Navigation, music streaming, maps) I get less than a day (8-10 hours). So if this is happening now, I wonder how bad it will be in another few months (1 year of ownership). But again, that is fairly heavy usage. I don't talk a lot on it, so that part of it is not as important to me.

This is the best phone you can get for $179 outright. If you're not wanting overkill on specs or price and not wanting to deal with a slow glitchy phone, this is the phone for you. The only thing I have found a little disappointing is the screen. It feels like the 2014 (2nd gen) model has a slightly better looking screen, but after owning both models I could not go back. The added features in this phone counteract the screen. Features like LTE, Moto Display, and the latest Android version (5.1.1 Lollipop) with very stock software are just some examples. I can get two full days on one charge as long as I have been using the phone "normally." If you go out and do a lot of cellular internet use (not on WiFi), then you would want to charge the night before for sure. Currently using mine on Cricket (AT&T) network in southern Alabama and get better signal strength with this phone than I have in the past with Samsung or iPhones as coverage is a bit spotty in my house with all carriers.

I got this for my kid and it works well.  I bought the Moto X for myself before this 3rd Gen was out and this is what I would buy for myself if I needed a new phone.  Battery seems to be longer lasting than my Moto X too.

My Moto X got an upgrade to the latest Android OS (6?) and the Moto G did not get a notification until about a month later.  I wondered if it would get the upgrade because of the length of wait.  It did and latest version of Android works great.

I got this because I was a bit tired of paying the hidden high cost of a smart phone device and this Moto G fits the bill for exactly what I wanted.  It is really convenient that it accepts the micro SD cards.  I put a 32GB card in it the day I gave him the phone and we loaded it up with his music and a couple movies for a trip.  He loved it.

It is great that you can direct pictures and video to write to the SD card and not the system memory.  It frees up the system memory for apps.

I would buy this again.  In fact I did, for my wife.  It works well for her too.

My only issue is in this day and age 8GB seems unreasonably small, given the low cost of memory.  This one has 8GB and my Moto X has 16.  This has little effect on performance but it does matter when installing apps.  16GB is more convenient even with the SD card slot in the Moto G (FYI, the Moto X does not have a SD option).  They should all have 32GB system ram these days.  There is no reason not too.  Add $10 to the cost if you must but it should not be necessary.

I purchased this phone from Amazon right before Thanksgiving.

At first, I was overly pleased to have this phone; everything worked as advertised, great LTE reception on Cricket here in Central FL...apps worked smoothly, pictures are OK, voice was clear, screen was just the right size, charge lasts about two days of normal use.....I was thrilled to have a great phone at a great price.

However, just three (3) weeks into this new phone I get a "SD card suddenly unmounted" message..which means that I can no longer access my SD card and all apps that were moved to it are unavailable. When I reboot the phone the SD card shows up in "Data Storage" in the settings...only to vanish with the dreaded "SD card suddenly dismounted" message a minute or two later.

This is obviously not a problem with the SD card, but the phone itself. I contacted Amazon and they are promptly sending me "another" Moto G3 phone....I am left to wonder what I will receive at my end..a refurb or a new-in-box replacement. We'll see.....

Anyhow, like I said I was initially thrilled with this phone but am happy that I waited to rate this item; I figured that I would wait for a month before I gave an honest rating. Glad that I did, as this phone didn't make it three weeks before there was a MAJOR problem.

Based upon the eventual outcome, I will change my rating to reflect what I finally end up with and what Amazon's final response will be.

To be fair, I hope to raise my ratings for this phone; Amazon has been responsive and I am only having to wait a few days for its replacement. We'll see how this turns out...

* UPDATE *
Well, Amazon got on the ball and sent me a brand new replacement within 72 hrs. I am impressed  !!!  Additionally, the new phone doesn't have the "SD card suddenly unmounted" message. Of course, neither did the phone I am replacing ( initially ). I am happy so far with Amazon's prompt response and if this phone works as it should I will update my rating to reflect 4 or 5 stars. Let's give this a month or two....

* 2ND UPDATE *
Well, I received the 2nd phone in  a timely fashion; but after three (3) weeks of use the same problem emerges: The SD Card won't work again. Works fine for awhile and then quits recognizing the card altogether. You can see the card temporarily when you reboot the phone, but it becomes unreadable after 1-2 minutes. There is absolutely nothing wrong with the card, either.

Contacted Amazon and they are sending me a third (3rd ) phone. If this one doesn't work then I will be receiving a refund.

REDUCED TO 1 STAR. THIS SUCKS.

I really wanted to like this phone but there were just so many things with it that forced me to return it.  For starters and the biggest of all is the wifi problems it has, every single wifi I was connected to the wifi speed was uselessly slow, like 2g speeds, across multiple routers and I worked with support for days trying to figure it out including hard resets, cache wiping, the works, nothing worked.  So I returned it, I also tried the alcatel onetouch idol 3 4.7 and that too has the same wifi problems as well, and the only thing I can think is that they both use the same snapdragon 410 processor, so there is some issue with the snapdragon 410 and lollipop where the wifi is extremely slow on it.  But the lte data is blazing fast, but I don't want to waste my limited data.  Also this does not have a notification light which sucks, the moto display doesn't pulse when you have notifications, only when you bump it.  I also had issues with the screen being not very responsive and having to tap things multiple times, also a nightmare for swipe texting.  Camera was also mediocre, not impressed.  Overall I think this phone has majorly missed the mark.  The wifi issues need to be resolved and the moto display needs to be tweaked so it pulses like a notification light than that would be doable. I can't recommend this phone do to the issues I had with it.

I enjoyed having this phone for some time, it has all everything you need on a droid phone, and the battery life is the best I've experienced so far.
However 8GB of internal memory is just too little, you won't be happy with it. You'd think you can extend it with a SD card, but it's really not a solutions: apps when updated are moving back into internal memory, and it's a constant squeezing-sweeping game.

Another problem that the phone seems to damage SD cards. I've head it for 6 months and the SD second card in a row becomes unreadable after being used in the phone, and I have never had issued with memory cards in any devices all my life. So I'm returning the phone.

Phone frequently freezes due to lack of memory.  I'm not even doing much other than Facebook and Email.  I realized after I bought this that it is very low on ram relative to other phones.  I would give it 0 stars but I'll give two because it is waterproof and doesn't come with a bunch of apps from carrier.  Other than that disappointed in the lack of ram.

Although initially excited to receive the new Moto G which I had researched in depth and read positive reviews about, as soon as I booted it up I noticed it had a faulty screen. Please see the photos of the yellow line running vertically through the right side of the screen. This is actually a great phone.  For the price, I was not expecting much, but after using it for the past couple weeks I am very satisfied.  My previous phone was an Iphone 5C, and I accidentally dropped my phone and cracked the screen.  I'm with At&t, and did NOT want to do their new plan with At&t Next.  To get a new Iphone was something like $27/month for 30 months which is $800.  Their other phones are around the same price, and I really do not want to pay that much for a phone.  I really just use it to text, make calls, and check traffic.  I was also looking at a Lumia 640, but I am ultimately glad I went with this phone.  I like both phones, but the lack of apps on windows phones is a killer.  I don't use many apps, but the apps I use, I use frequently and aren't on windows phones.

Compared with my Iphone 5c, I actually find this to be a better phone!  I've read reviews saying you NEED to get the 16 GB 2 GB ram version of this phone, but I can tell you it's not very necessary unless you really use your phone alot and maybe do alot of gaming.  I got the 1 GB RAM, and it is more than enough for me.  The onboard 8 GB memory is not much, but I just bought a $10 microSD card and bumped it up to 32 GB.  The old Iphone 5 actually has the same 1 GB RAM, and this hasn't lagged at all even when i've had alot of applications open.

It took me a little while to get used to coming from an Iphone for the past 5 years or so, but I am glad I made the switch.  The camera is great, and I like how it's connected to the Google line of products.  I use Gmail and Chrome, and works seamlessly with their apps and I imported all my contacts and information from those accounts to the phone.  I started getting irritated with Iphones when they made that switch in the connectors.  I had alot of stereos and stuff that had those old connectors, then they switched to the lightning usb.  Also with Iphones, whenever theres a new Iphone and you update to the new IOS on your current one it happens to "mysteriously" slow down to a crawl and is not very usable.  Pretty sure they do this on purpose to get you to buy a new Iphone.  Anyway, I got tired of Iphones and am ultimately satisfied with this android phone.  It does everything I need to, and is pretty user friendly.  I just took to my local At&t store, and they put in a new sim card for no charge.  Have had no problems with service and calls are clear. Battery life is great
Good one.

It's beautiful, fast, runs stock Android so just about everything now available is supported. You don't have to wait on Samsung or the carrier to approve your phone or any available upgrade. I have the GSM unlocked unit. Camera is good. No finger print reader. Very affordable.

This phone was a lemon; the SIM port was defective, a problem others on the MotoG users group also had.

MotoG has been developing a rep for problems with their SIM slots, and Consumer Cellular is big enough they should be able to produce ONE PIECE MICRO-SIM CARDS. There's no excuse to forcing customers to use flimsy 3 part SIM cards.

For under $10 I could get a precision adaptor from MicroSim-Shop dotcom. There's a video on how this works at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WjLk-amds9k.  If Motorola would test and approve the use of THIS adaptor,  I will happily pay for the adaptors, wait for delivery, and finally install my SIM card. In that case we will stay with Motorola. Motorola would benefit even more than I, because they would have a solution to a problem for now and perhaps license the design for the next generation of phones.

However, if Motorola will not test the MicroSim-shop adaptor,  I'll have to find a brand with a better reputation for SIM slots and a better system and reputation for servicing their new phones.
