Let me start off by saying I have had an iphone 5c for the past 2 years. Before that I used galaxies and I never really liked the galaxy brand. Too many problems, bloatware was too heavy. I consider myself a pretty tech savvy guy and I really just wanted a phone that worked.

While my iphone never had any major problems other than slow down due to software bloat, my phone was nearing the end of its life. The phone began getting sluggish and I started having minor problems after the 2 year mark. So when I set out to look for a phone I did heavy research. Battery life, a simple experience and price where the factors I used to determine my selection.

After reviewing tons of Phablets, I landed on the Moto 3g and I never really looked back since.

So lets break down what this phone does right and what it just does okay.

What is does okay
--------
Camera - While not the most high end camera in the world, it certainly does the job. I was able to take some great pictures and if you don't like the camera then simply buy new software on the playstore. It's not the most high end camera but I can't really say much seeing as it works.

Screen - Coming from a Iphone users don't realize their screen maybe one of the best features. While this screen isn't bad, it certainly isn't great either. It gets the job done while just being a little above average.

No Verizon/Boost Mobile/Sprint Support - While not a huge deal breaker, I am little shocked this phone doesn't support all the carriers rather than GSM only. I am waiting for Moto to break out with a universal phone but maybe that will never happen.

What is AMAZING
----

Android 6.0 and Battery - I have no idea if it's doze or if it is the phone but damn. This battery is crazy on standby time. The usage isn't too shabby either. With Marshmallow and active display I can get 1% battery drain out of 3 to 4 hours of standby. That is amazing! My iphone when in standby using to go %5 every hour regardless of use or not. Moto wins in this department.

Speaker - While it is not the clearest speaker in the world. I am impressed by how loud the speaker can even get. I am so use to iphone bottom facing speaker that I am not sure I can go back to another phone that has one that isn't facing you. It makes a difference and it's more than you think.

The Experience - Even though many people might not understand this. I enjoy a very plain vanilla android with no re-skinned apps or anything just a pure android experience. Man does this phone deliver. It's snappy and fast. No studder, lag or anything. I am overly impressed that this $200 phone can bring the experience of a high end flagship device. Very impressive.

What it doesn't do
----
No finger print reader - Not a deal breaker for me. While I would certainly enjoy to see Moto head in that direction with the next device I wouldn't consider it a problem at this price point.

Quick Charge - A little sad that some kind of quick charge couldn't be thrown into the phone as it takes the phone a pretty long time to recharge something like 3 to 4 hours from dead which is kind of a pain but considering how the long the battery last it's not very hard to assume that I can get to a charger by night and just let it run.

Overall Impression
---

While there is lots of things to love/hate about this phone. No one can argue that this device feels like a much high quality item than what it really is. Essentially the feeling you will having owning and using this phone is why would I pay for a $700-800 device when I can get a comparable experience out of a device 1/4 the cost of most flagships?

I would never recommend this phone to a power user. But coming from a Iphone 5c this device offers me enough productivity and battery to be more than enough for your average consumer who doesn't want to blow the bank. If I could give half a start I would say that the few issues above take off about a half a star to make it a 4 1/2 star product but still worth more than 4 stars.

Buy this phone. You won't be disappointed.

--Update---

After spending about a week with this phone. I can tell you there are some huge issues.
Number One the phone is unlocked however it only works with GSM carriers. It's bigger brother the pure works on ALL carriers. That's right. ALL carriers.
Number Two the phone's moto specific software was apparently removed if you update to Android 6.0. As a matter of fact many Android 6.0 features were not even listed.

Want to wave your hand across the screen to wake? That's gone.
Want to move contacts from one phone to another? That's gone.
Want to name your phone Billy? That's gone.
Want to switch to Ambient Display that comes with Android 6.0? It's not even in the damn menu.
Want to wake up the phone? I hope you like hitting the side power button because your going to be doing it a lot!

I had high hopes for this device but sadly, I can see now. Spend the extra $200 and just buy the Pure/Play. Not only will you get a better phone but you'll get the whole moto experience without it being watered down. I am highly disappointed that not one review mentioned that this phone has a completely vanilla watered down moto experience. I know Moto is getting rid of many of their apps because of google and doesn't see the point in keeping them around but honestly, I was buying the phone for the extra functionality and this phone doesn't have it. The pure does. Seems like a gimmick to me, buy the more expensive phone.

Remember, this phone is orientated for budget purposes so the budget within the phone really means budget. You do get relatively smooth transitions between tasks within the phone because it's stock android, but you are limited on the storage. If you don't download music, games, or take TONS of photos, then you're fine with a few apps for texting, watching videos, taking a reasonable amount of photos. I really like the phone. For <$200 dollars, it's a fair offer.
Let me bring up the photos and picture reference for a minute. The camera on this phone is not good when compared to a Samsung phone (Galaxy S5 is what my other phone is). You can see the difference just by switching phones. If you're not that picky about how SUPER great the quality is of the image, then you won't be bothered by the image quality. The quality is standard/good to say the least.

Would I reccomend this phone? Well, depends on your situation. I would say yes if you're looking for a phone that's a cheap price with limited storage space and decent camera quality. Remember that you can always insert a micro SD card for extra storage.
I would say NO for an alternative phone if you're wanting to "upgrade." If you're planning to upgrade, lets say from an iPhone 4 or Samsung Galaxy s4 or 3 to something newer or "better" then I would look somewhere else. This phone is simply for the price. And with all that said, the price stacks up fairly well to what it's containing within the Moto G.

Great size, good specs, and amazing camera quality. And it's less than $200, while an unlocked Galaxy S5 is almost double the price. The only flaw is the low internal storage, but you can easily upgrade it with an SD card. My T-mobile Sim card fit perfectly in it and I get quality reception (though it may lag in a few areas). Overall, this is a superb smartphone any person should get if they don't want to break their wallet looking for a good quality phone.

This is only my second smart phone, and have only been using a smart phone for less than a year. The first was a BLU Life one. A good (for the money) phone, until I took the latest update. It locked up tight as a drum. Dead as a mackerel. I then decided to go with an established name. I read review after review. And this is what I decided on. There are apps out there that help extend the already long battery charge. I'm not much of a game player on the phone, so that may have something to do with it. Calls are crisp and clear. And the camera is exceptional, in my opinion. Without a rubber phone protector, it feels like it wants to slide out of pocket. It seems to me to process quickly, with very little lag. A good low budget phone. I've taken the time to learn how to operate it, and so far, it's flawlessExcept for this new Marshmellow update. It's been updating for two days. It seems to be stuck at 67%. Just no luck with these updates. I guess I can live with it though. You got to expect such things from low budget gadgets. As long as it continues to work, I guess I'll be happy with it.

I purchased the 16GB/2GB RAM model through Motorola directly, and have had it for about a month now. This happens to be my first personal smartphone, and my first Android one at that. Before this I had used an old iPhone 4S, which has acted as the home phone for many years now. My search for a new and affordable phone was an arduous one, so for my review I think I will be focusing on value and offer some input on the other options a buyer faces at this price range, and hopefully it helps someone make up their minds. But, before that I will be making little notes about my observations with the device itself. Edit: After finishing up my “little notes” I realize that this is pretty much an article and I am so sorry. Tl;dr I like it

Unboxing) The factory plastic screen protector seemed to be stuck onto the screen due to the weather and atmospheric changes during shipping. The screen protector is supposed to stick, I mean, but normally the pull tab is easy to use, but in this case it too was sealed to the screen. Why didn't they just let the tab extend past the screen so this doesn't happen? No matter, if one encounters this just get a piece of scotch tape and lift it up with that. I heard tell some buyers were worried about scratching their screen trying to pry under the tab, so I thought I'd mention this.

OS) Right out of the box this phone came with Android 5.0 as expected, a few days later I got the update for 6.0, installed that with zero issues. Buyers now may get 6.0 preinstalled. Set up was very simple and easy for a first time Android owner, as was playing around the interface and learning how to make things exactly how I wanted them. The OS is very clean of aftermarket software. Only a few Motorola apps exist, besides the default Google apps. All of these can be disabled at the least.

Storage) With the 16GB model, there was only 11.81 GB total space with 10.75 GB available to me. The OS itself uses the remaining 4.19 GB of space. There is an available SD card slot that is officially compatible with SD cards up to 32GB, however many users report that they can use a 128GB card with their Moto G just fine. Storage should not be an issue on this phone.

Battery) This phone has a 2470 mAh battery. Lasts fine for a couple of days of casual use (infrequent texting/calling, checking email and calendar, using calculator, etc), and a full charge takes around 3 hours. But if you have the chance you really should be topping it off to between 40 and 80 percent. I'd recommend you read up on how to care for your battery. Other phones may advertise batteries with a larger capacity, but that doesn't necessarily mean it will last longer. What also matters is what that battery is trying to power. Above I mentioned that the OS is very light, and below I will mention the...

Display), which is 720p (or 720x1280) on a ~5 inch screen. It looks relatively sharp, however 720p on a 5 inch screen is really pushing it. Any larger a screen or any smaller a resolution and it would look like crap. So they picked a good middle ground. A 1080p resolution would certainly draw more power, and a smaller screen would probably turn away the ever increasing amount of people who want bigger screens. It is supposedly an IPS display, however the quality of blacks (is this the contrast range?) seems to be poor, more similar to my experience with TN displays. There is no apparent screen door effect in normal use. Only if you stick your face a couple inches away from the screen just so you can find something to complain about. However you WILL notice the screen door effect if you try to use this phone for VR. 720p won't cut it for that. The screen will not wow you, but it definitely looks good and is more than sufficient.

Sound) There are two front speakers, but do not be fooled. The top speaker is for calls only, whereas the bottom speaker is what will play media and other sounds. It's really crappy as I expected. Upon connecting headphones however, (Which for the first couple of times might be a really tight fit. Make sure you keep pushing until you hear a snap. This sounds terrible doesn't it?) the sound drivers turned out to be pretty decent! I put my Sennheiser HD518s into these and while they don't sound as good as on my PC, music is still really enjoyable. This is something that, ideally, you shouldn't have to mess with blindly, but if one is using cheap earbuds try playing around with an equalizer. This has a big impact on sound quality and soundstage. Enthusiasts will not be impressed by the quality but they should also know better than to expect much more from a phone, especially in this price range.

Design)  This phone looks really good imo! The back has a textured feel that is perfect for palm grips. Place your index finger in the Moto Dimple and allow this to guide the rest of your hand under the phone. Very slip-resistant here. I favor a claw grip, and while the phone isn't huge, those with small hands or short fingers might have to operate with two hands. With a claw grip, I can almost comfortably traverse my thumb all the way around the device, with some adjustment. I believe the Moto E has an advantage here, on the sides. This phone has a smooth, sort of slippery finish on the sides which I don't appreciate at all. It at least definitely needs some textured areas on the corners for when you pull the phone out of your pocket. Huh, haven't seen a phone with that yet. The slim design, at approximately 1 cm naked, enables smooth insertion and extraction relative to the pocket. Besides the smooth sides, my only other gripe is that the back of the phone is not flat, so I cannot have it sit on the table and use it without having it spin around a little bit. There are probably cases out there to remedy this, however.

Camera) I'm not big on taking pictures or video so I can't say a lot here. It looks quite good. I do notice that the taken image always looks different than what is shown on the camera when I am taking it. The focus circle also does not always convey to me what exactly will be in focus, and is somewhat finicky. I prefer the iPhone's tap-to-focus because it immediately shows me what the image is going to look like, and it's faster and more accurate.

Reception) I keep hearing that Motorola phones have great reception. I live in a small midwest city surrounded by trees and all I ever hear about is how terrible everything is. That also includes cell reception. I'm with Consumer Cellular using AT&T towers and everything seems fine so far. Reception is a lot better in my home than the iPhone 4 on the same network (it displays similar connection but call quality and consistency is superior), and in town I've had zero issues as well. I can't really provide a chart of measurable evidence on this, only anecdotal, so if you put no weight on this factor then I don't blame you.

It's like the Wii all over again) I can karate chop the air and turn the flashlight on. I just did it. It works. Takes a bit of force though, you have to chop the air like you mean it. You can flick the phone a couple of times to turn the camera app on too. Doing this a second time will alternate between front and rear camera. Why would you do that though when you can just move your thumb over and press the button to do that? These are kind of finicky and you'll probably look like a dork shaking your phone around. But on the off-chance that it works the first time you will look awesome.

RAMBLING:
The Moto G 3rd Gen is a an enticing value at $180-$220 unlocked. But this price bracket is around the low end of mid-tier phones, and includes some fierce competition. Most notably, the ASUS Zenfone 2, Alcatel's OneTouch Idol 3 (which also has a lower spec $180-ish model), Sony's Xperia M4, Huawei's P8 Lite, LG's Nexus 5, and even Motorola's own Nexus 6.

Which phone you pick may come down to what you are looking out of your device. While other options, such as the Idol 3, may provide you a better multimedia experience with its better sound quality and higher pixels-per-inch count, and others boast very impressive yet affordable technical specifications like the Zenfone 2, I would suggest that the Moto G offers to be a more dependable and practical general-use phone. A strong battery life, Motorola's supposedly solid cell reception, good camera, slim yet grip-friendly design, water resistance (not waterproof), and a very clean (and currently up-to-date!) interface and operating system are the main attractions of this phone to me.

With that perspective, however, do you really want to spend upwards of $220 for a phone? Motorola itself offers great values with the older Moto E and Moto G lines. I guess what I am just trying to get at is that this phone is in a very awkward place.

So, if you choose this phone, what might you be giving up?  As far as performance goes, my Moto G just flies non-stop with 2GB of RAM (and many say this is true with 1GB as well). I've experienced no issues with this phone, even when gaming (to be fair I don't do much except Hearthstone and the occasional random puzzle games). I think you will be satisfied using this for general use. Power users probably won't be looking at this price range for a powerful phone in the first place. So if that's not an issue, what is?

1) The Idol 3, at very similar price points being $180 and $250 respectively, has a reversible display, meaning it is equally functional upside-down as it is right-side up. Many times I wish my Moto G had this feature, but to be fair it is a rare one and I only know it exists on the Idol 3.
2) The Moto G does not have dual SIM slots like the Zenfone 2, P8 Lite, or the Xperia M4 Dual
3) No fingerprint scanner as several higher priced phones have.
4) Does not have fast charging capabilities like many of the other phones I mentioned seem to do.
5) The Moto G does not have a replaceable battery, but neither do any of the other phones I've been talking about. This design seems to be necessary to ensure water resistance, however.
6) The display on this phone has too low a pixels-per-inch count for you to experience VR. You will have a screen door effect if you try, which ruins the entire point.
7) There is no NFC support (if you need this you will probably know about it already. I personally have use for NFC)
8) There also is no magnetometer. This worried some people about Google Maps not staying relative to your facing, as well as compass apps being nonfunctional. However both of these things work just fine on my phone.

What are you gaining then? An attractive and mostly functional design, customization through Motomaker, a strong, dependable battery, a good camera, and a clean operating system. And a karate flashlight.

I would suggest checking your preferred carrier's offer on this phone. Many carriers do not sell the 16GB model of this phone, but they may have good offers on the lower end model. Consumer Cellular, for instance, is selling the Moto G 3rd gen 8GB for only $150, last I checked. This is a great value for a carrier that has a demographic seeking simple and practical solutions, and the phone's performance definitely matches that sentiment.

The 8GB/1GB configuration is a better value than the more expensive model, which effectively only grants you 1 more GB of  RAM for $40 more, seeing as storage is not an issue with a microSD slot.

So one must ask, what are the benefits of this extra gigabyte? Well what RAM allows you to do, very basically, is to have your device do more things at once. If your phone has a small amount of RAM, it will become bogged down using resource-intensive apps or multiple smaller apps running in the background. Also, one must take into account that the performance of a phone will inevitably decline as it ages. Looking at my memory manager on the phone I see on average I use about 1GB. So 1GB is certainly enough for the number of background apps I have going, and many budget and mid-tier phones use this amount, but having 2 means that I will not become bottlenecked with my current usage if I need to use more, and it will take a longer time for my memory performance to deteriorate. It's also possible that if my phone had only 1GB of RAM, I could be using less on average and have a little bit of wiggle room, as my system will try to optimize performance. Overall a single gigabyte isn't a huge deal, but it's something to take into account because it does make a difference depending on how you use your phone.

If that's worth $40 to you and you really want this phone, go ahead. A little investment to add to the longevity of the phone's smooth performance. I think most people buying this phone would opt for the cheaper option regardless, as it is the much better value.

I wish I had returned it during the return period. Many reasons, chief among them: 1) Screen is laggy and too sensitive when using web browsers. Very easily invokes hyperlinks when scrolling pages. 2) Very difficult to use with aftermarket car mounts. A "cradle" type mount is awkward because of the location of the volume control, forcing you to put it off-centered into the mount. Magnetic mounts don't work because they interfere with a magnetic sensor associated with the optional flip case that turns the screen off when you shut the cover. So, the screen shuts off when if you try to use it with magnetic mount. I have not found any setting to turn off the sensor. On paper, it seems like a decent phone: good price, NOT TOO LARGE, and admittedly has decent battery life. But I miss my Nexus 4. I really want a good performing Android phone that isn't huge and I guess I'll keep hoping one comes along.

I am writing this review based on my experience with the 16GB storage / 2GB RAM model of the Moto G 3rd Generation.  Currently, only the 8GB / 1GB model is available for order on Amazon, so I had to order mine directly from Motorola.

My only serious gripe with this phone is with the availability of the 16GB / 2GB model.  It was back-ordered when I first tried to order it, in early August, and Motorola's website is pretty clunky with the order process.  It may allow you to go through the entire process, then tell you in the end that some part is not available, and not finalize your order.  Once you manage to place your order, they charge your credit card within 24-48 hours, mark the phone as "built", but don't ship it for maybe two or three weeks.  At least that was my experience and I have read many similar accounts.  If you question their customer service via online chat, asking about a ship date, expect to get some vague non-answers in some very bad English, but also expect to get a coupon off of accessories available on their website.  Overall I can't say it was a good experience.  I'd rather just order the phone from Amazon, get it in two days for free with Prime delivery, and not deal with Motorola's order system at all.

Having received the phone, though, I can say that I am perfectly happy with it.  It's my first Android phone, although I have limited other experience with my wife's phone and a tablet mainly used by my sons.  I manage both of these devices but don't use them very much.  My previous phone was an iPhone 5S which I used for two years.

I would say that my Moto G3 is superior to that iPhone 5S in nearly every way that matters to me, except that it doesn't have a fingerprint reader.  It is stable, fast, and hasn't given me any trouble at all.  I like Android 5.1.1 better than I was liking IOS 8.  I have used quite a few apps on it, and done some casual gaming, as well as basic use as a phone and texting device, without any issues.  Also it doesn't have 5Ghz wifi but I wasn't using that on my iPhone 5S anyway.  I sold my iPhone through Gazelle for $150 and got a brand new unlocked Moto G3 for $219.99.  I also switched from an AT&T 2-year contract to Cricket and that is saving me about $45/month for an equivalent network and data allowance.  So I'm happy with my new device, and with the money I'm saving by not upgrading to the latest flagship phone for $700 or a monthly fee spreading it out over time.

One word of advice on Cricket and other wireless carriers and using a Moto G, or a Moto E like my wife owns.  They will try to sell you a "universal" SIM kit with a nano-SIM and an adapter for micro-SIM slots.  Don't use these adapters in these Moto phones.  Motorola tells you directly not to use them, and people tell horror stories about getting them stuck and breaking the pins in their SIM slots with them.  Of course their phone support and people at their retail stores will tell you it isn't a real problem, but it is.  Get a real micro-SIM.  I went to some Cricket store across town that had micro-SIM cards in stock, and still had to harass them into selling me a micro-SIM instead of one of their universal bring-your-own-phone kits.  Then I couldn't activate it through the Cricket website for some reason.  However, Cricket has awesome support by email through a tool called Zendesk, and they had me activated with my number ported from AT&T in around an hour.  Not sure what is happening with other carriers, but from what I understand, most of them are pushing these universal SIM kits with adapters.

If I had to make this purchase again, I probably would, unless I needed the phone quickly, which might be a problem with their back-order situation.  The other phone I would consider would be the new Nexus 5X, for $399, but faster and with a better camera, a fingerprint reader, and more timely updates and patches for Android.

These seem to kick in when I plug the phone into the charger.  It resolves itself with a restart, but it can be pretty inconvenient. This is a good, basic, cohesive phone that's greater than the sum of its parts; and more nimble, considering its modest innards compared to the beefier Android contemporaries. It's not an explosive Shelby GT 500 that showcases a mighty, throaty presence... it's a Prius C that glides effortlessly through the competition. No frills: No 1080p, no stereo speakers, no fingerprint reader, not even a discrete notification led (actual bummer), NFC, magnetometer, gyroscope, or premium metal anywhere (just plastic). Another con is that the only way to get to the battery is by removing the screen in front - something to consider if you plan on keeping this phone for more than a year or two. Obvious bonuses are that it's stock Android, very responsive, unlocked, first in line for updates, waterproof, fast-locking gps, virtually lag-free, and cost effective.
Deal breaker for this price. The only con is it doesn't have a gyroscope sensor, so it doesn't support any VR applications

Moto G 3rd gen review:

I considered this purchase somewhat carefully and have a lot to say about it. I've only had the phone for a week, but I'm quite satisfied so far. It does all the things I need it to do, plus a few extras thrown in.

What I was looking for:

Price: $200 or less
Size: Must fit in hand
OS: Anything but Apple (price requirement probably excludes that anyway)
Features: WiFi and LTE capability, FM radio, average camera, removeable but decent battery, headphone jack, decent memory/processing and enough storage for some books, music and podcasts.

What I got:
All of those except the removeable battery, plus water resistance and a relatively crisp screen. I did have to buy an SD card to expand the storage from 8GB to 32BG, but I didn't mind that. I don't use a lot of apps, but if you do, you'll probably need more than 8GB.

I also like the quick access to the flashlight and camera. The first time I used the flashlight and camera, a pop-up informed me that I could access either with a chopping motion (flashlight) or twisty motion (camera) even when the phone is locked. I don't know how common that is on smartphones because this is my first one, but the little tutorial tips were easy to follow. The only drawback to this is that someone could take pictures with your locked phone. In order to view the pictures already on the phone, however, it has to be unlocked. This doesn't bother me personally, but could be an issue for some folks. I believe this feature can be disabled.

What I use it for:
Texting, getting email alerts so I don't have to be logged into my work and personal email AND near my computer to know I have an email, calendar reminders and general organization, alarm clock, Kindle replacement (I just can't read on my desktop), amateurish snapshots, Netflix, web browsing, viewing and editing work documents on Google (just quick, little things, not extended work), maps, flashlight.

What I do not use/need:
1) LTE. I don't have a data plan and don't intend to get one any time soon. I wanted the capability so I'd have that option, since I don't plan on buying a new phone until I absolutely HAVE to. I can't comment on how well the phone works for on-the-go data b/c I use it exclusively with wifi.

2) Camera. I mean, I use the camera, but I'm not any sort of judge of the quality. I've had trouble with blurry pictures, but I'm 99% certain that's user error. When I take my time, the pictures look good to me. Better than what I really need, in fact.

3) Navigation. Since I don't have a data plan, I only use it as a replacement for a physical map. I download maps ahead of time if I think I'll need them, but otherwise I don't use this function. I suspect the quality of the GPS would have more to do with the network than the phone anyhow.

4) Lots of processing power. I'm not a "power user." I have a desktop for that. When I'm out and about, I'm doing something else, so I don't have a lot of need for a lightening fast, top-of-the-line model. However, I have to say that for the price, this phone moves pretty fast. There's very little lag in the interface and most web pages and videos load without issue on wifi. The Imgur app runs pretty smoothly, even when viewing large albums. So does Google maps. For me, the phone goes above and beyond in that regard.

Other models I looked at:
BLU Studio Energy
Moto E
Samsung Galaxy Core Prime

Why I chose this model over those:
The Studio Energy's superpowered battery appealed to me, but when I tried one out at the store, it moved rather sluggishly. There were also some reports online of stability issues and defects. The volume and quality of some of those reports gave me pause.

The Samsung model seemed good on paper, but some reviews mentioned that the display and camera were subpar for the price. The price difference between the Moto E and Moto G was small considering the extra power the G has. And I liked the way the display on the G looked: very crisp and pretty visible in full sunlight if you turn the brightness all the way up. All in all, the Moto G just seemed like a better phone for the price. And everyone I know who has had a Motorola phone (including me) liked it and experienced few problems.

I'm sure there are other phones out there that would have served my needs, but so far this one is working out splendidly. It definitely doesn't feel like a budget phone. The only cons are the battery life and the fact that the battery is not removeable. Not that the battery drains THAT quickly; even with a few hours of listening to the radio and streaming video, it still lasts the whole day. But if you're going to use it a LOT, you'll need a battery pack or something. The fact that I can't remove/replace the battery bothers me, but again, the tradeoff is the water resistance. My previous (flip) phones sustained water damage just from being in my pocket when it was hot out (EVERYBODY SWEATS, OKAY?) or rained. According to one review I watched, the phone kept playing video when submerged in a glass of water. Though it should be noted that it is only water RESISTANT. Motorola doesn't claim that you can submerge it in liquid without damage. However, I do like that little bit of extra protection, since I want to be able to keep the phone for a while.

If I run into problems, I will update, but so far I'm very happy with this purchase. I feel like I got a lot (though obviously not all) of the benefits of joining everyone in the 21st century without paying the horrendous price tag that many people pay. ($800 for a phone? You could put together a reasonably decent gaming desktop for that. It's just not my bag.)

For the price , I suppose this is a pretty decent phone. The screen resolution is nothing to write home about but then again, the dimensions aren't overtly trying to be a phablet. The camera is decent for taking your average shots / selfies etc as well. The phone can get just a tad toasty but then again, what phone doesn't when multitasking. It's nothing to be concerned of however like the Sony Xperia. Battery life as well is pretty average. Several other reviews boast amazing charge times as well as the ability to hold a charge tremendously longer than any iPhone or samsung, but again, it all comes down to what type of apps you're running. Chances are, if you're considering buying this phone, you're not going to be doing heavy gaming or running CPU intensive programs. A final take-away, if you need an android phone, don't want to pay mid tier prices, value quality over looks and functionality, then definitely this is the best phone out there ATM. And hey, if you're the type of user that might jump in the shower, and realize you forgot to text your boss telling him you're running late, no need to wipe off your hands...haha!

Bought the 8 GB model for the wife. At first things were great, but within 2 months the storage limitations became a huge issue. Motorola left less than 5GB for apps and media. Many apps, such as Whatsapp cannot be moved into the SD card and so, even keeping just the basic apps, we can no longer install any apps or even upgrade existing apps due to lack of space.

To make things worse, the 32GB Sandisk class 10 card we bought for the phone keeps getting "SD Card removed unexpectedly" message, making the phone completely useless. Upon complaining to Motorola support, they came back stating that the 8GB model can only accept cards with speed of class 8 and less. This is not stated anywhere in the product specs.

Stay away from the 8GB model.

Update: I was able to make the Sandisk card class 10 work by reformatting it to FAT32 with allocation unit size of 15K instead of 32K so I added a star.

I still recommend purchasing the 16GB model and not the 8gb due to the app storage limitation, at least until all apps can work from the SD card.

Android has all the apps I need - I use iSyncr to sync with iTunes (you have to create custom playlists to sync podcasts), Google Photos for picture enhancing, Just Cleaner for optimizing and WebRoot for anti-virus protection. As the title says i bought one and after doing the chop movement for the flash to enter, i saw how the flash would start and then shut off immediately, this happened many times over after a few days ago when the camera did not work i got this: CAMERA BUSY, i downloaded many camera apps from the play store and some of them said that my phone does not even have a camera!, then i googled this problem and noticed that this is a mayor problem with moto G 3G and moto X. Ironically when you do the chop and swivel  motions you are actually disconnecting soldier points on the phone,  the camera can detach from it little by little, i had to return it to amazon(this is a hardware issue because nothing worked: wipe cache, restoring to factory settings, deleting camera app cache and even updating to marshmallow from lollipop), the cameras were very good but was the thing that mostly wanted me to have it and it died. google: CAMERA BUSY MOTO 3G and you'll be surprised, im not saying: do not buy the phone, im saying do not chop or swivel or you will regret it. Gave it 1 star because you dont manufacture a phone with awesome shortcuts and have the shortcuts themselves be the culprits of the cameras disconnection or faults, that is simply poor quality control and arquitecture.

I ordered the 16GB 2GB version of this phone. It is working very well for me. I use Cricket Wireless which uses AT&T towers. The phone works with LTE and sometimes drops to 3G because of coverage in my building where I work. Overall this is a solid phone which runs flawlessly. I also purchased the Cimo clear case for it and it fit my phone very well.

**Update - After having the phone for a month I found some serious issues with it. Phone gets significantly hot for no apparent reason. Bluetooth stops working while in the middle of a call. Disconnecting and reconnecting Bluetooth resumes connection but it shouldn't work that way. Wifi connection at my house does not go over 1Mbps. Other devices are always around 12Mbps. Called Motorola to get warranty replacement and they will charge me a refundable $100 hold and a no refundable $25 fee for a Month old phone that is their defective product! Here's the kicker, my pristine new looking device will be replaced with a "like new" device. Not sure if I will be buying Motorola products again. Very bad experience with this phone.

*Note* I have the 16gb with 2gb of ram purchased from Motorola.

I must say that this is an awesome phone for the price! I'm coming back to Android from an iPhone 5 and I miss using bigger screens and having so many customization options available. I had no issue with activating it with at&t prepaid either with awesome LTE speeds in my area. I've been using the phone for about a week now and have come up with a list of pros and cons for the phone.

Pros:
 - Battery life, I easily get through the day without having to charge before I get to bed.
 - Radio, Motorola has been known to have awesome radios in their phones, and the Moto G picks up good signal everywhere I used it.
 - MicroSD, good luck getting a phone from Samsung or Apple if you like to save pics or music to an sd card
 - Customization, Moto has some sweet options if you're buying straight from them.
 - Front facing speaker
 - Size, it's a nice size and for a 5inch screen its comfortable to hold and manageable with one handed use as well.
 - UI, pure Android with Moto enhancements is just smooth as silk!

Cons:
 - Screen, It is pretty bright and a nice size but Moto should have tried to put in a 1080p display here
 - Camera, it's not bad. it uses the same sensor as the Nexus 6 but it's not winning any awards either.
 - Processor, Moto should have definitely used the snapdragon 615 instead of the 410. If you play a lot of games on your phone, you may want to look at other options.

Overall for $220, you get a lot of phone for the price! clean Android with fast UI and Android 6.0 coming soon, Moto G will sure see it before many other phones out there. Moto knocked it out of the park once again!

This phone has been working pretty great for a few weeks now so I thought I'd put down the pros:
- small-ish 5 inch screen is still fits in a jean pocket
- battery life is AMAZING, I'm able to go through a good 10 hour day (with messaging, navigation, game playing, web browsing here and there) without freaking out about my phone dying
- smooth interface, for the average user (i.e. me) I don't notice any lagging switching between apps or playing simple games or other tasks like voice commands and whatnot
- really nice front and back camera!
- Under 200 dollars!  Although I bought the 2gb RAM version which was 220 and totally still worth every penny
Cons (there's really only one):
- No LED light notification.  Switching from Samsung galaxy which has multicolor LED notification so I can tell if I have a message, email, or any other notifications from across the room.  With this phone I have to physically pick it up for the Moto Display to turn on to see if I had messages or emails, I cannot get it to activate with a handwave like I think it's supposed to.

All in all, solid phone for under 250 dollars. When it comes down to it, I'd pick battery life over LED notifications any day.

I bought this phone to replace my 1st gen Moto E. My review will consist of pros and cons in comparison to the previous phone. If anyone thinks my cons are incorrect, do let me know how to fix these issues, as I just may not have figured them out yet:

PROS
1) Faster, more memory (2gb RAM, 16 GB space)
2) Flashlight feature
3) Better camera (13mp) and 5mp 'selfie' camera
4) Not pre-loaded with too many google apps
5) already updated to android 6.0

CONS
1) no LED notification light. In fact, display screen for notifications is just annoying, as it shows icons and you have to swipe to see your actual notification.
2) putting the phone on silent automatically puts the phone on 'do not disturb' mode so you don't get any notifications except for alarms. You have to swipe to see the rest of your notifications (ex- from apps) as they hide behind a black screen.
3) battery seems to run out a little quicker, though it does usually last a whole day.
4) screen is bigger (I prefer being able to hold a phone with one hand and this is slightly large), Not a con to other people, I know.

I bought the Motorola G 3rd Gen. as it is consistently chosen as the best phone in its price range. I am happy as long as I can make calls, surf the web, listen to podcasts, and take the occasional picture. Brand, design, ultrafast performance, etc. aren't high priorities. Ultimately, however, I decided to return all three phones I received from Amazon and opted for the Nexus 5x, which is about double the price. The poor reliability of the Moto G isn't worth the savings. I recognize that some problems might be related to Android, T-mobile, or (very possibly) user error and not because of the hardware...but in some cases it was definitely the hardware.  In short:

- Originally ordered on Jan. 1, 2016. This phone worked but it would not read the SD card, even though I could format the SD card when I first installed it. The SD card is the same as the one offered on the Motorola site (SanDisk Ultra  microSD card 32G) so it should be compatible. The second problem is my bad in that I was using the iPhone earbuds initially and they worked with the phone with no problems. After a while, they stopped working but this is probably an Apple thing and nothing to do with Motorola. I had no problems after switching to a different pair of earbuds with a mic (but not after a failed experiment with the SoundPEATS QY8 Bluetooth 4.1 Wireless Sports Headphones, which are passable as earphones but pick up tons of background noise when talking on the phone).

- Ordered a replacement phone on Jan. 30. Long story short, SD card was fine but incoming calls went straight to voicemail and outgoing calls would connect but neither party could hear the other. It wasn't a problem with the SIM card as I did not have this problem with the original phone. Just in case, I got a new SIM card from T-mobile but still had the same problem.

- Just in case I was just really unlucky, I bought another Moto G on Feb 22.  Didn't work out of the box.

- My Nexus 5x just arrived today. We'll see how it goes.

- One saving grace is Amazon's service. Extremely quick to send replacements and painless return process. After reading about Motorola's awful customer service, I'm glad I didn't buy directly from them.
Excellent buy. Easy to use

This is a great phone , but what can you say , it's a Motorola . I haven't had a bad Motorola product ever. This phone is not loaded up with a lot of junk apps . As close to a Google Phone (Nexus) as you can get in my opinion .

Her only complaint is the sensitivity of the screen touch. It opens things when she is trying to scroll. But this is a matter of becoming used to it after using a much smaller screen for 3 years and less sensitivity.
Don't buy this phone.

This review is for the 16GB Internal Memory G3 with 2GB of internal memory. At first, I bought the 8GB model and like it, then I decided to buy and try the 16GB and so glad that I did. This phone has truly surpassed my expectations!  This Moto G 3rd Generation Phone is just the right size, not too large or too small! For you the reader, my goal here is to give you every day and practical uses regarding this phone.

PROS:

+ SOUND QUALITY FOR PHONE CALLS and MUSIC ETC - This phone has LOUD SOUND QUALITY in speaking and listening is EXCELLENT with no distortion, much better loudness than my old Samsung Grand Prime! Even on speaker phone, the sound is plenty loud for me to hear and others hear me just fine. (I have slight hearing loss so I have to have a LOUD phone and I am so glad that I bought this phone, just one of the many reasons why I am very pleased with this phone).
**Also, the music plays plenty loud on the phone speaker.

+ Tethering....Normally I do not tether but to find out if the Moto G 3Rd Gen tethers well, I tried this and YES it works using the Moto G 3rd Gen. Well, I wanted you to know that this phone does have Tethering abilities (USB or Bluetooth, Hotspot). It works flawlessly for me. However, since I have a small data plan...usually do not tether yet I  tried to see if jt worked...it works great. I used the Bluetooth tethering and paired the Moto G with my Tab 3 8.0 (WiFi only tablet) FIRST. Then I Bluetooth tethered. Very fast.
You will need to check with your carrier and be sure that it is OK to tether on your Data Plan. For me, I am on WiFi 95 percent of time and no need for Data, so I only tried tethering to test this phone in that regard.

+ WiFi Connecting/Speed of WiFi - Very, very fast--in fact in the back of my home, I still get 4.5 bars of WiFi signal on this phone! This I tested using my home router and on the go at many hotspots with WiFi. . Other hotspots: No problems at all connecting and staying connected on these. And I found the speed still high at home with several devices connected to the router, no loss in speed. **Note that I had other phones before this one and for me, none gave me the quick connect and overall speed as this one!

+ Internet & Webpage & Video Viewing - The Chrome browser does a great job, however, I use Maxthon Browser with great internet viewing results and it renders webpages quite fast for me.

+ No lagging at all and no freezing, I have found this phone to very fast and responsive. This phone is a joy to use because of this!

+ Internal Memory and Storage Space – This is a plus and a minus, however, as for internal storage space (after I finished adding my personal apps in internal storage and updating today to the large 177.3 MB update), I still have 2.99 GB left and I added lots of apps such as Facebook, Twitter, Hangouts, Skype, Amazon Music, Amazon Shopping, Walmart and a large Office program, but I DID NOT ADD any games as most games take up too much internal space.
Internal Memory – To conserve my memory and add to my battery life, I downloaded the ES Task Manager (free) from the Playstore. It frees up my memory, and my battery is better and I am very pleased with the performance of this phone using this app.

  + Screen Resolution - VERY CLEAR! The colors are vivid and the fonts, icons are very clear. Even though this is a 5 inch screen, when I view pages on the internet, the text is clear and pictures very clear and colorful! For me, I can read everything well without my reading glasses.

+ Camera improvements/Performance (I am very impressed with this camera) – I had a Samsung Grand Prime with an 8mp camera and I took camera shots using both phones outside and inside. This Moto G’s camera produced much sharper and vivid pictures than my Samsung Grand Prime!
+ 13MP Camera – This camera I love, and I found that my pictures came out clearer and better when I did this:
-  I DO NOT USE the AUTO setting, just the flash or no flash and my pictures come out better now. My outdoor pictures I do not take in bright, bright sunlight, I take in shade and my pictures come out better. **Notes regarding the camera: I found that if I leave my flash either on or off (and do not set to AUTO), the pictures have come out so much better now (clearer with better color etc). I took some outdoor shots and indoor shots after this and found that my pictures really looked nice! Since I updated today the OS, I now have Nighttime Abilities on this camera (new).

+ Lollipop Pure Android Experience - Since this has close to pure Android with no overlays over it or bloat ware apps,  just the essential apps installed, this is a leaner phone that uses much less memory and battery than the ones that have those overlays and are not straight Android! This means that Lollipop OS runs better and faster than I expected.
**I have found NO LAGGING, NO FREEZING. For me, I have found this phone to be very peppy. Today, September 19, 2015, just received a stability update for Lollipop from Motorola. The update was large at 177.3MB.

+ EXTERNAL SLOT FOR MICRO SD CARD – My 32GB SD card works great. However, just to test this phone, I first added my San Disk 64GB Micro card that I had placed music on. My Samsung Galaxy Tabs (and Galaxy Prime) read it, however, this phone would read it but the 64 GB card would not work in this phone. Note that I found that my 32GB SD card stores plenty of my music on this and photos etc and still have over 6 megs left!

+ Data/WiFi Info -  For me, I do  not have LTE where I live but the data is VERY FAST, it opens webpages lightening fast!  I do not use that much data as I have WiFi at home and find FREE WiFi in most places that I frequent as Coffee Shops, Hotels, Library, Airport and more...
This very fast in WiFi at home or wherever I find Hot Spots. Also, when I have to turn on data in my car, the speed is very fast as well on this phone. I find it FASTER than my older Samsung Galaxy Grand Prime was!

+  Office Program with the phone - Found it to be OK, but I went to the Playstore and installed WPS Office (which lets me edit, save, view in MS Office types and also view PDF files). There is also a MS Office App (free) in the Playstore.

+ Music Player - This phone comes with Google Player installed and I like it OK. It does play music that is stored on my external SD card nicely and saves new Playlists OK (and Google Player also plays music from the Cloud). However, let me suggest RocketPlayer (free) from the Playstore. I like it because my music is on my external SD card and it plays it in playlists or from my folders etc. I have already created my playlists on it and the sound is superb!

+ Home Videos - The stock video player is OK and plays MOST home videos, however, may I suggest QQ Player (Free App from Playstore and the ONLY one I recommend as it plays every home video I tried).

+ Battery Life/and more…- Excellent and the best I have found yet! Since this phone does NOT come with lots of bloat ware and useless apps, this helps the memory to run better and the battery last longer! In fact, I have gotten a day and a half of battery use (I turn off WiFi when I am off the internet or email etc).  However, I run my brightness at 100%. So on an average day, I get at least a full day with about 15 percent left (sometimes more) and then I charge it overnight.
There have been some reports of people saying that this phone runs a bit warm/hot. Personally, my Moto phone runs about 85 degrees F to 97 degrees. It will go up to about 97 degrees when I take lots of pictures using my flash or if I download apps from Playstore, but it goes right down to about 85 degrees in no time. This is very normal because many of the newer phones these days with the larger and faster processors run warmer than older phones did in yesteryear with smaller processors.

+ Bluetooth Speed and Performance - The Bluetooth paired quickly with several devices and copied files at a great rate of speed.This is the fasted Bluetooth connection that I have ever used, easy to connect to every device (phone or tablet) or speakers, headsets etc!

+ OTG - The micro USB port on this phone is OTG (On the Go) compatible, this means that if you order a OTG Adapter Cable, then you can place a flash drive, USB Mouse and more into this phone. For me, I have been able to place my 32GB Flash drive in this adapter and easily copy files from this phone to my flash drive!

+ Very, Very Peppy and fast - The added memory of the 2GB really makes a HUGE difference. Found the response on this phone to be very peppy and fast, no lagging!

+ File Manager - I went to the Playstore and found Astro File Manager, it is easy to find my files on my SD External card and also on the phone. Liked it so much, I bought the AD FREE version!

MY PERSONAL BOTTOM LINE:  If you are trying to decide between the 8GB or the 16GB, I suggest that if all possible, you spend the extra 40 dollars and purchase the 16GB, plus 2 GB RAM. It is so worth every penny! After I install LOTS of apps. including Twitter, Facebook, Office and more, I still have about 10GB left for more apps if I want to install later on.

BOTTOM LINE FOR YOU...Should YOU consider purchasing this phone at 16 or 8?  1) Yes the 16 I suggest, if you are looking for a easy to use and reasonably priced Android smartphone that has wonderful battery life, let me suggest this phone to you.
2) Yes if plan on installing LOTS of apps. However, if are careful with the apps you install, then you may do OK with the 8GB however, after you install just a few apps, you will have 2 to 3 GB left or so and you will have to keep an eye on the apps...

If you're taking the time to read these reviews, you're probably on the lookout for a capable budget phone that'll "get the job done". Well, I'm here to tell you that not only will this device do the job, but it'll do it so well that you'll keep having to remind yourself how little you paid for it! I'm sure I don't need to sit here and list all the positives about the Moto G. Seriously, scroll up! Look at what you get for such a small investment! Need some water resistance? Excellent battery life? A phone that actually uses a microSD card (so few phones even give this as an option these days)? How about a 13MP camera, something you would never expect to find on a budget device? 5" HD screen? You and I BOTH know that's the perfect screen size. If I wanted to carry around a tablet, I'd go buy a tablet! 5.5"+ screens? No thanks! Near stock Android without bloatware? Yep, you'll find that here, too. Oh, and let's not forget that it's one of the few phones to actually put the buttons on the correct side (in my honest opinion)! Pure convenience!

Last, and definitely not least, UPDATES. You can take solace in the fact that this phone will receive updates super quick for a long time to come (even the 1st generation Moto G has Lollipop), not just because of bloatless Android, but the Motorola name!

From a price/pros standpoint, this phone currently leads the pack in 2015! Trust me, you won't be disappointed!

Much love & respect for Motorola who've outdone themselves once again by giving us the best budget smartphone money can buy.
Motorola's Moto G series started and so far has been on the forefront of budget smartphone market which has now gotten so better & competitive that they've been dubbed "Flagship killers".
I can start to bog you down with all the techie jargon & technical specifications of this phone but it is unnecessary, leave those to the 5% nerds & geeks. It all bogs down to the overall day to day user experience the 95% typical phone users like me(and probably you) who just wants to get first and foremost, a clean software experience not filled with unnecessary OEM bloatware that I never use or need, nice & comfortable feel on the hand, reliable internet access, access to emails, access to social media(fb, Instagram, Whatsapp, tumblr...) , be able to listen/stream to my favorite radio stations & podcasts, get navigation information, weather updates, SMS(do people still use these??), Voice/VoIP/Video calls, the occasional selfie/group photo/random photo moments, listen/stream music from my playlists or favorite artists on Soundcloud/Spotify.... watch cat videos on youtube ;-) , organize my life and track important dates/events with calendar/notes, casual browsing or shopping on Amazon/ebay/bestbuy, play candy crush etc... Then this phone can do all that without a hiccup. No gimmicks, just pure day to day usability.

And the best feature in my opinion from Motorola with all their devices apart from the very competitive pricing, is the guarantee for timely(maybe not so much after Lenovo took over from Google) software updates. I bought the Moto G 1st gen back in 2013 when it was running Jellybean, I was able to upgrade it through over the air(OTA) to KitKat & handed it down to my little sister who now has upgraded it to Lollipop without a hustle, just purely OTA updates from the good people at Motorola themselves. I have a Moto G 2nd gen from 2014  and this Moto G 3rd gen from 2015 & I believe all(or at least the 2nd & 3rd gen) Moto Gs will get the Marshmallow update(I heard soak tests are already underway in select European and South American Markets) ISN'T THAT AMAZING!!!!!!! Motorola made a promise & they've been able to keep their word, maybe not as smooth & timely as planned but still, they kept their promise and I respect & admire them for that. We usually know that other OEMs only update their flagships(non flagships are left to be forgotten) in a usually messy and painstakingly long wait. Except google's own Nexus line of devices, It is unheard of in the android ecosystem(due to fragmentation) for OEMs to support 3year old devices through OS updates. Much Kudos to Motorola for changing that, other OEMs should follow Motorola's example, there is nothing worse than buying a 600$+ flagship android device(let alone a non flagship) that will be a dinosaur in the next 8months just because the OEM didn't provide an update of the latest Android OS version either because they see no financial value to doing so or they are struggling with the mostly unnecessary customization to the lousy skins they slap on stock android.

VERDICT: If you want a phone that is RELIABLE, has GOOD PERFORMANCE, has a REASONABLE PRICE and will be able to KEEP UP(software updates) with the android ecosystem for the next 2 or 3 years(maybe more...) then look no further, this is the best companion for you. Otherwise if you want a 1000$ phone to match your 2000$ bracelet or if you want a phone to power your hadron particle collider in your secret lab down your basement or if you want a phone to photograph distant stars and solar systems in the sky at night or if you want a phone to record 5hour 4K videos of your cat purring or if you want a phone to play the latest version of GTA/FIFA/Fallout/World of Warcraft/Halo/Assassins Creed/Tomb Raider/... in 4K at 10000FPS or if you want a phone with battery life to last you through the imminent zombie apocalypse... sorry, this is NOT the phone for you, please look elsewhere( I know a friend of mine who is crew in the Enterprise NX-01, he's been to places where they might have what you are looking for. He might be able to help...)

Believe it or not the phone is hard or impossible to answer.

The ui that presents itself is inconsistent. If the phone is unlocked, meaning you are past your pw screen, you either get a big blue screen which consumes the whole screen or a small - too small - little white dialog which has 2 choices : decline and accept.

If you hit this deline / accept dialog in the wrong spot ... which is itself ill-defined yet easy to do, then you lost your one chance to answer your phone, buster, so try harder next time.

 If you get Big Blue, which I can't emphasize enough is in no way related to the state of your phone, then you can hit it anywhere EXCEPT on the little phone icon in the middle because that "means" reject call....

When I said earlier that you lose the ability to answer the phone if you hit the decline / accept dialog wrong, I meant it. You cannot thereafter hit any button, real or virtual to answer the call, nor can you go into the phone application and hit any button... in fact, when your phone rings it is WRONG to hit your phone icon and go into the application at all...you cannot answer the phone via the phone app...

This is worse than an merely ordinary level of bad UI...it reeks of the effect of software patents.

One company patents a ui for answering the phone then another patents another way and soon all the natural, obvious ways to answer the phone are some corporation's private property which is their "competitive advantage "and the phone you buy has to live in the UI ghetto.... that's software patents at work for society.. creating a new class of non-contributing rentiers and UI ghettos instead of having a world with a shared commons of good ideas, like the first 50 years of software development gave us.

Here's to the degenerate coke-snorting lawyer class and the "progress" they bring society.. here's to the CAFC and other Ayn Rand freaks with their non-reality based, just-so fairy tales involving perfect markets populated by perfectly selfish consumers whose only concern is (because everyone is a sociopath in their theories) maximizing their personal profit ....  all those Platonic economic theories swirl around and around the ideosphere like a gigantic floating pile of ocean trash and what results is....I can't answer my phone.

The Moto G is a terrible phone. I am generally an iPhone user domestically, however when I travel I like having an unlocked GSM smartphone ready for me to connect to a local network directly. I previously used an LG phone to do that, but as a result of age and obsolescence, it was time to get something new. I chose the Moto G, and boy did I choose wrong. Because of the bloat not only of the Google apps on the phone (which is reasonable, after all it is an Android) but also several worthless Moto apps that don't have any clear purpose, the user is left with 4 GB of storage. One can expand this storage with an SD Card, such as this Samsung 32GB EVO Class 10 Micro SDHC Card with Adapter up to 48MB/s (MB-MP32DA/AM) which I did, but the ability to move photos over is very clunky and no applications can be stored on the SD card. Still this wasn't my real problem. My big issue was trying to get data from the SD card onto my Mac. I tried using the USB hookup and the Android File Transfer application from Google to no avail. I then noticed that I could push all the photos onto Drive, but in the process this seemed to be saving duplicates on the phone, overloading my hard drive, and killing the phone. While the phone still runs, I can only make outgoing calls and no one can call me inbound. It now seems next to worthless. I'm very disappointed and will not buy this product again and it makes me hesitant to reconsider Android as well.

After having the phone for a month and a half I believe I can say I've experienced both the highs and the lows of the device.
Pros:
+ nearly stock android
+ long battery life
+ sdcard storage, the new unicorn of features for smartphones
Cons:
- running more than a few apps causes it to slow down and even lock up
- when it freezes, it gets super hot (that was fun to write)

Perhaps my use case has me using too many applications or background services (two email clients, a music player, and a few web tabs), however I hoped that the Moto G would be powerful enough for that limited situation, slow downs I would expect, but I never though that I wouldn't need to buy hand warmers this fall.

It's a great budget phone marred by a serious issue. The speaker stops working unpredictably. This means, you suddenly cannot listen to voice/music through the speaker, and worse of all, you won't hear the phone ringing. Researching this on the web, I found this to be a common problem with moto g3. The build otherwise is solid, the look and feel is great, the pure android experience is the tops, android updates work without a hitch, all positives. Stuff that can be improved include the display quality, camera, and the music playback quality (may be there are apps that can do a better job playing back music, but the native playback is very weak). I'm mentioning this only to note that there are so many Chinese phones with much better specs on these. I guess you're trading off build quality and moto brand against better specs within this price range.

Because of the overall quality, I ended up returning this, but replaced it with the 16 gb model of the same. So far, the speaker has been working. Keeping the fingers crossed.

Just some quick first impressions. I really wanted the 2gb Ram/16gb model but it wasn't available and I was hoping to get a feel for the phone early on with some business travel coming up (review is based on the 1gb/8gb model).

Packaging is clean - the device comes in slim packaging compared with previous Nexus 6/Moto E packaging, however is nicely protected. When unboxing and flipping the phone over the first thing I noticed is the instructions on the back panel of the phone on how to properly remove the cover/reseal it in order to get the best water resistance. I also ordered a blue cover from Motorola directly which should arrive next week. While the back cover is removable the battery is not user replaceable - this may be a factor for some but I carry an external battery when travelling for work.

The device itself does not by any means feel like a budget smart phone. It's leaps and bounds better in terms of overall build quality compared to some recently released devices such ... Read more

I purchased a first gen. Moto G for my wife several years ago. She not only loved it, I found it to be very responsive and not prone to lock-ups like many of my previous Android phones. I later purchased a Moto X, which I liked very much - but managed to kill it in a pool only 4 months later (sadly, I had not purchased the insurance). I somewhat reluctantly purchased a Moto G 3rd gen for myself, and was very surprised how little performance difference there was between the X and the G (more of a feature-set difference, actually). I very much like the fact that the new Moto G is warranteed against immersion for up to 30 minutes (haven't put it to the test, but nice to know).

Mere weeks after I purchased mine, my wife ended up dropping her first Moto G in water (not warranteed against water damage), so she needed a new phone. Moto G 3rd gen for her! Fast forward 3 months, my daughter lost her phone (my old Nexus 4) somewhere in Arizona. We purchased yet another Moto G, 3rd gen - for her. So - all told:
• 1 1st Gen Moto G
• 3 3rd Gen Moto Gs

We could NOT be happier. I probably will never purchase another model until Moto/Lenovo discontinues it. This is my 6th Android phone, so it isn't as if I have no experience with them. This one rarely overheats, has a super long battery life (I can really use it during the day; worst-case it has 30% battery left when I get home), and the performance is really quite impressive for the price.

The color is actually prettier than in the picture, I love it. I have a toddler who has dropped my phone more than several times and it has never been broken or scratched. I attribute the protection to this phone cover! Great purchase

This phone (Motorola Moto G (3rd generation) - Global GSM - Unlocked - 8 GB White) is supposed to be, the "global version" but it doesn't work with all the 3G or LTE Network bands... So its not a GLOBAL VERSION!!

I trusted in the title, dont make the same mistake. Don't buy it, without first know if your network carrier supports this bands:

HSDPA - 850 / 1700(AWS) / 1900 / 2100
LTE - band 2(1900), 4(1700/2100), 5(850), 7(2600), 12(700), 17(700)
Warning!! do not order ..after charging for 2 hours it only charged 20%!!
